Review title: One of the best movies I have seen so far
Review_body: There are numerous Hollywood movies of zombies and a very successful TV show. Some of them are great with mind-blowing action, CGI, stories and characters. Most of them revolves around a main character who comes in to save the day or teams up with characters who are used to further the story of the MC. To my relief, Train to Busan was nothing like that. This movie is about survival. This movie portrays what people are willing to do to save their loved ones when a crisis breaks out- a very shocking, unexpected and terrifying crisis. How the worst in people and also the best is exposed when people need to survive. It's not the most perfect movie. There are flaws and plot holes but you can easily overlook them with the excellent directing and acting. The director did an excellent job on expressing the intensity and the grim atmosphere for the story to fully grapple us. lastly, Hollywood movies could learn a thing or two on how to represent emotional, human side of the movie in a masterful way.

Truly the best zombie movie i have seen so far. its like game of thrones but a talented guy wrote it instead of that miserable lard. i cant even being to describe it, the movie is perfectly paced and highly grounded in reality, or at least as much as is possible with these kinds of movies.it holds true emotion and family bonds, its truly a great movie. Giving a perfect 10 even though the movie does take some liberties to insert some suspense. Definitely highly recommend watching this movie.the child actor also gave a very good performance, never expected this from Korea.

Review title: Subtitles been turning you off? OMG, YOU WILL GET PAST IT
Review_body:
So I had heard of this movie for a while before watching. I absolutely LOVE zombie movies and tv shows. But the idea of having to pay close attention to subtitles, kinda turned me off, as I'm not used to having to do so.
I AM SO GLAD I GAVE THIS FILM A CHANCE.
It is now one of my favorite zombie movies. The acting was incredible. And I love their twist on a zombies weakness. 
Would love to see a sequel to this movie, as it would be interesting to see how people managed with the said weakness.
Such a good film but my frustration is 10/10. Everyone made such dumb moves and decisions. Can't stand it. I've seen too many of these. Jesas.

I love zombies. I don't love the constant stupid decisions of characters in zombie movies that allow everything to descend into chaos. Train to Busan lacks a lot of the stupid found in most zombie movies while still providing drama, kind emotional moments and terror!The infected are done so well! I've never seen snarling, ratcheting, flesh devouring fiends portrayed with such skin crawling realism.Highly recommended for zombie fans. Do watch in original language with subtitles if you need them.

There was not one minute I didn't enjoyed watching this movie. The writers did not waste a second on this. From beginning to ending the plot was very well packed with climax after climax.The movie started off a bit clichè with a single divorced parent and a daughter he cannot spend enough time with because of his work and busy schedule. It's a very good plot to see their relationship develop through the movie though. Which by the way was a success.The important part of this movie which makes it so unique is the fact that this movie does not, ironically, focus on the zombies. Their origin, cure, strength is not the main focus and will not be explained. What the movie actually represents (and this is my own interpretation) is the interaction within a group of people (representing a society). This movie shows how people react to a 'threat' emotionally, morally and by action. Zombies are just supposed to represent a threat in this movie but still be a tool to make it an action-packed horror movie on the way.Most of the movie take place in a train and creates an original and claustrophobic atmosphere for a zombie movie. The story was pretty close to a real life experience with no really weapons involved or ordinary humans who turn out to know everything about the zombies and fight them as if it was originally their job. Their were a few minor things in the movie that didn't seem to make much sense though.The main character was not that likable in the beginning. Towards the end he started to grow on me. His daughter, thank god, did not turn out to be a clingy annoying daughter. She was suspiciously calm during the whole process of surviving. The husband of the pregnant women was probably my favorit character as for the baseball boy who was quite likable as well. Very colorful characters. The villain a little exaggerated in my opinion but acceptable if you think about the fact that he is supposed to represent the ignorant part of todays society.I spent two hours on a great zombie movie and would recommend it to everybody.

Train to Busan is proof that with effective visual storytelling, you don't need exposition. I watched this movie in Japanese with Japanese subtitles, and despite my Japanese being just "Ok" I was able to understand everything the movie was trying to convey. Sometimes simple is best.The film starts off with a protagonist who comes across as selfish and unlikeable, but slowly becomes the hero as the story progresses. However Train to Busan manages to do this without shoving it down the viewer's throat. None of the characters seem like important people with special knowledge, they're all just normal people in a bad situation trying to survive.The choice to confine the story on a train, for the most part, helps the viewer feel a sense of claustrophobia throughout the film and it makes every action the characters make a little more nail biting.While Train to Busan may not be the most original idea, it proves not everything has to be. When done well, even the oldest stories can still make a viewer feel fear, tension, and apprehension for 2 hours.

Review title: A zombie movie made me cry?
Review_body: This movie is beyond incredible. As someone who hates zombie movies I went into this expecting a few cool action scenes and nothing more. But boy was I shocked and amazed by what I saw.This movie is the only zombie movie I've ever seen that actually brought me to tears more than once.The characters feel so real and their reactions are the cornerstone of this picture. The characters do not react in your typical "cool action movie" way, blowing zombies away at every turn. No, they are afraid, they are confused, they are selfish, they are human. They react in the way real people would react in this kind of situation. Some step up and go after zombies, some stay behind in fear for their lives, and some are putting others in danger to save their own skin. The reactions and characters are so diverse and I'm sure if I went in depth, each one could easily represent an aspect of human nature in survival situations.The setting is perfect and the things that happen are as realistic as a zombie movie can get. A huge moving train packed with zombies, no way to communicate with law enforcement, and no way to see what's happening in the outside world other than the TV. The only thing they can do, is survive until the train stops. This mix of danger and being left in the dark creates tension that leaves you on the edge of your seat, biting your nails, praying for the characters safety.Speaking of the character safety, in this movie, no one is safe. I won't go in depth with the more gruesome moments, but rest assured, nothing is off limits. You truly get the sense that anything could happen to these people at any time.The emotional parts of this movie are also an enormous strength. Since the characters all feel so real and so thought out, whenever one dies it feels like a stab in the heart. Even when an extra dies, the acting is so well done that instead of the typical "there goes another one" feeling typical of zombie movies you get a feeling of dread, that's constantly encroaching upon everyone involved.All in all, this movie is a perfect example of what a zombie movie can truly be, instead of the same action star schlock usually made. I encourage everyone to watch it at least once, to experience one of the best movies of all time.

As a Korean or Asian zombie movie, I get it that it is a rare production done relative well. But in a larger scheme of things and comparing with all the zombie movies that have been done to death especially in Hollywood, this movie is AVERAGE. The zombies are unoriginal and so similar to World War Z, this might as well be a called World War Z: The Busan Contagion.That Korean cinema touch of inserting emo moments to every genre is just so cliche, worn out and in this case applied without much thoughts. Review title: This film will make you sweat
Review_body:
I thought I was bored and done with zombie films. Maybe not for all time, but for the foreseeable future. That was before I stumbled upon Train to Busan.
In this south Korean film from 2017 we follow a young father with a boring suit that has lost the spark for life. He boarders a train with his estranged daughter. During the start of the movie, we have these pretty common clues about animals and people staring to act weird. In many ways Train to Busan follows the zombie film playbook. But I think it goes furthers with creating very heartfelt stories. One of the biggest possibilities there is with the genre is too elaborate with the characters relationships to each other and especially to themselves in a time of horror.
They succeed in this area many times, not just with the dad and daughter who are perfectly portrayed. We have this young baseball player and his girlfriend as the cute couple. Then there is a pregnant couple who works as the comic relief when together. But the man in this couple is very skeptical about our protagonist father whereas the woman is bonding with the daughter. The chemistry is priceless between these characters and it makes the whole movie. At the same time, it is one of the better action movies in a long time and the suspense is world class. I was sweating almost the whole movie.

Review title: Well worth seeking out this South Korean Zombie epic.
Review_body:
Train to Busan makes most zombie film look pedestrian in comparison. While you average zombie film moves along like a car stuck on the M25, this movie moves along like a Porsche on high-speed racetrack.
The director throws every thing at the movie including the kitchen sink. Like all great movies you really care about the characters, which makes the hyperactive, never let up ending almost unbearable to watch.
Its 2 half hour running time allows the script to include every plot device seen in most recent zombie movies. But most importantly it never drags. Its claustrophobic setting allows the director to pull off some unique moments of crisis. Also GCI and stunt team do a very good job here.
Highly recommended not just by me but by the director of Sean of the dead no less, how can you go wrong.

Some may not agree but this has to be the beat zombie movie I ever saw. To me this has topped Shaun of the dead, Night of the living dead, Day of the dead(1986) and Dawn of the Dead remake.I just rewatched it for the the first time in 5 years since I first saw it on Netflix US(now on Amazon and Shudder). The claustrophobia and emotion is still amazing and recommend to watch if you love zombies and action pack films that waste no time kicking off the plot.The sequel wasn't great but wasnt bad but there no way it would be on par of this film and neither that of the animated prequel. Hate that that my country is planning a an American remake!

As a lover of all things zombie related. I've seen alot of zombie films and this is the best of the lot in my opinion. The zombies themselves are freaky and horrible, they move as you would expect them to, falling from ledges, running carelessly at potential victims, slamming into walls as if they have no self-awareness unlike other movies where they act somewhat intelligent as they negotiate the terrain. There are some really tense moments in it and really cool scenes. If you love zombie movies this should be definitely be on your to watch list.

Review title: A Zombie movie like no other.....
Review_body: Train to busan looks the usual zombie flick...with a normal zombie movie plot line...where it scores is it makes us feel for the characters within no time...Director keeps us guessing until the final minute of the film..which is no easy feat...Underlying social commentary in the film adds to the story...zombies are not the scariest things in this movie...humans are more scarier basing on the decisions they make...It has gripping screenplay...and all the usual zombie flick stuff like... near misses, blood and gore, stupid decisions characters take( i hate it when they do that)....What is different is..zombies are super fast...(like world war z) No mention about the incident which made zombies( for a change, i liked it)Above all its a film about a father and his daughter...A zombie film with a surprising emotional connect....Must watch....its not what you expect..itz better..

I'm not a big fan of South Korea movies or TV shows but I love zombie movies so I try this one and I didn't disappointed as a zombie movie fan!Train to Busan is such a great ride, Well Written, A lovely cinematography, wonderful performances with the main cast, and especially unbelievable performance with the zombie actors to this film!This is the film that you will never forget this year because its all in one movie, FUN RIDE, ACTION RIDE, SUSPENSE RIDE AND DRAMA RIDE! Hollywood zombies films I think you need to think twice now because South Korea zombies will eat you alive!4over5

This is probably the best dramatic zombie movie. I m not a fan of zombies tbh, but this movie made it look so real that you feel for the leading actors. The drama is on point with a father and daughter relation in the heart of it. Train to busan is worth watching.
Train to Bushan is one of the best movie in its genre. It is a must watch zombie movie.

Review title: Had no idea zombie movies can make you cry too
Review_body: Not a huge fan of zombie movies but this one is an entirely different story. It's not just a zombie movie it's an emotional roller coaster ride.

Review title: A zombie flick with some extra character development
Review_body: Not a huge fan of zombie/disaster movie genre in general, but thought that due to the direction this could be an interesting take on it. Though the characters all had a little bit of depth, and the setting of a train was fun, the movie did just boil down to a zombie flick: 1 dimensional characters that do everything you expect (greedy COO, all-sacrificing masc-dad, hopelessly in love teenage boy, matronly and caring pregnant mom), tons of impossible to escape scenes, and death of nearly everyone except for a chosen city of people. The relationship between the father and his daughter was the most interesting, seeing his lack of empathy and the ideas he was teaching her about selfishness flipped on their head when disaster struck made for a nice (albeit cliche) arc, but other than that the film was just ok.

Going in to this movie I heard some hype but really I wasn't expecting alot, but when it was over I sat there speechless. This movie truly has a fantastic sense of thrills that make you hold your chair tight when watching. This movie uses it's shots and space the best way. One of my favorite zombie films in the last couple of years.

An emotional thriller which will not fail to keep its audience engaged until the last.
It has perfect mixture of emotions(especially the last scene will leave you crying). I really loved how certain small scenes also portrayed different emotions very well.
The casting is awesome, everyone has done the best job and correctly understood the character, especially the little girl has done fabulous work , having all expressions to the point. The makeup artists are also an important part in its success giving a real look of zombies.
The movie is not perfect as must I say because at some points the actions and decisions taken by the characters will really piss you off.
Even after certain mistakes in the movie, it is a MUST WATCH because of the acting, cinematography, makeup and screenplay.

This movie was one step above watching paint dry, which is only one step above watching grass grow, hence 3 stars.It was like a movie written by a bunch of third graders from the California school system.Really boring and silly. I'll never regain the time I wasted on this drivel.

If you like "zombie," films, as I do, you are sure to like this one. As in any drama you must identify and care about the characters. Plenty to care about here. Some original zombie action themes added to the enjoyment.

I was enthralled by this movie! I am so used to South Korean movies being cheesy chick flicks, but man this one was definitely not it! The whole premise of a zombie apocalypse has obviously been done a million times over, but the execution, the concept, the characters got me really invested. The acting could've improved a little, although, it is hard to judge completely since it is in Korean making it hard to hear the nuances of emotions being portrayed. The ending was such a splash of ice cold water after what was undeniably a roller coaster ride of emotions and thrill! Nicely done!

I'm not a movie reviewer but had to say that I love this film. I honestly have a hard time not giving this one a 10 based on how deep some of the scenes/moments make me feel - even on 2nd, 3rd viewing. This is just one of those movies that makes most everything else look like 2nd rate garbage. You can tell there was talent and love in the people who made this. Odd to say that about a zombie movie but it's just more than that ... and is a masterpiece. Bravo to all behind it - here's hoping they make more films this good!

This is the best "Zombie" movie ever made without excessive special effects. Its the only well made emotional movie against the background of zombie breakout. It really connects with each character of the story and also teaches high moral lessons in the time of dire consequences. It clearly shows each characters mindset and how they react to the situation. The protagonist's (Father-Daughter)story is very emotional and touches all the right chords of feelings. The director has used emotions so well that it really makes a mark in terms of direction and cast is superb with the little girl's innocent & pure acting skills. It is a journey which you would like never to stop and a must watch for Zombie Lovers.

I was kind of skeptical at first about this movie, but decided to give it a go and watch it. That was not a waste of time.Being a fan of The walking dead, World War Z, 28 days later and so on, this will be a definite addition to the list of great zombie movies.The youngest actress is captivating with her emotions,great talent. Good plot,great cast, characters you get to love and feel sad about, even shed a few tears too!Overall very impressed, now I am in a mood to look for more Korean movies to watch!

Review title: Investigate humanities ego-tripping psyche in a zombie movie
Review_body: I believe this is the best zombie film I've seen so far. It is not overdone, like so many of the big screen zombie films are. There is some kind of outbreak at a facility and people are evacuated. During the outbreak day a girl is going to visit her mother in another place. To reach the destination she has to take the train to Busan. This trip turns out differently than expected. During their trip there is a outbreak of a zombie sickness. People simply turn into zombies and try to eat non infected people. This outbreak also happens on the train. How will they handle it? Is there any way to survive this train trip and reach the destination? There is a lot of blood and splatter and if you are a sensitive person this is not a film for you. But if you adore zombie movies, this is one of the better ones. It is not overcooked, no this production is just right. It is enough of everything. Somehow this movie also investigates how far you are willing to go for your self interests. Are you willing to help other's on your way? Or are you ego, just doing what benefits you, even if that means other people dying? Somehow this is about how we people turn on each other in crises. So who are you, the good samaritan or the self-centered asshole? Well, I guess Train to Busan just puts all these things on display. You might even learn something about humanity watching this zombie movie. Interesting right? It's well worth seeing this movie. Sit down, be on the edge for a while. The grade is a grade set where I compare it with other zombie movies.
Most western zombie films are pretentious and take themselves too seriously. This is just a good old action movie that'll keep you riveted once you get past the rather slow opening.
Higky recommend, gooacting and story was a fresh approach. But geez this one is a sad one.

Review title: It is more than a zombie movie
Review_body: This is the type of movie u should watch... Without a single minute boring.. Beginning till the end.. It was nail biting end..GREAT movie to watch its got all the contents..climax was super..

I liked it!
I've watched it about 4 times now, once with no subtitles. Apart from the obvious cliche in all horror movies - that being how some people are stupid and stare at the drama happening in front of them rather than running - there are no complaints. I liked the acting and I believe the movie was done well, the acting wasn't terrible either. I like how it's similar to World War Z except Train to Busan is based solely in South Korea. Well done.
Dont have word what a movie, cinamarography, thrill , suspense, in every category this film is fabulous.
One of the best zombie movies i have seen. Again Korea shows that they can make quality movies. The little girl deserves an oscar.. amazing acting! Zombies were made really good.

Review title: One of my favorites!! Won't be disappointed
Review_body: I'm always skeptical going into new zombie movies Bc good ones just are made anymore most are B rated and the filming sucks. THIS MOVIE IS GREAT. Hollywood needs to take some tips for these people. They stayed within realm of what we know while introducing their own spin on certain zombie traits. Its has that edge of the seat, hold your breathe type scenes. It's got characters you can like and ones your screaming to kill already. Adding that it's on a train gives it a more be careful, watch where you go factor. I didn't quite catch how it started I'll have to rewatch to see if I missed something. For me it's a sold 9.5, one of my new favorites on up there with dawn of the dead (04), and this is just a me thing but it lost .5 Bc I wasn't as happy with the ending as I wanted to be but they brought it together wonderfully and respect their writing. So, go watch it!

Review title: Incredible how people gives such high marks for this mediocre film...!!
Review_body: I am surprised to see this film got such a high marks on IMDb!!! i found the acting of the actors mediocre at best...their reactions are quite fake, unbelievable...they cant convey the feeling of hopelessness, desperation and the decor could be hundred times better: nothing is in disarrayed, no litters found, no smokes, no debris except for few things...everything is so clean and i don't feel at all scared or anything.....It is such a huge let down. The worse of all is that the acting of the actors: main as well as supporting actors: they are not real enough and their emotions are forceful...i feel like they are all amateur....I have never seen a zombie in my life but i think the zombies in this film run too fast and very coordinated when they jump or chasing after people, it means when necessary to run after the uninfected ones. But when the uninfected ones fell, well, the zombies started to walk clumsily and slowly toward the fallen....like they knew their preys could not run so they, the zombies, do the "zombie walk" just to impress them !!! So fake that i found to be laughing at its poor, poor, poor acting.

This was one of the best zombie films I've seen. It has several sub-plots, intense action, lots of suspense. At first you'd wonder how a movie with zombies on a train could span 2 hours, but this film did it outstandingly well! I could easily have watched it going on for another hour.The scenarios are realistic (well as realistic at can be for there being zombies 🙂).The film also presented a theme of man's inhumanity to man on one side, and the selflessness of man for his brother on the other side - all in the midst of a life and death struggle. This was set up very well early on.It was interesting to observe the evolution of the main character as things progressed.It may not be to everyone's taste, it's not as gore-filled as some other films (though there is carnage a-plenty).Overall, I trilling film.

Hollywood till.now has produced over 1000 zombie movies in so many years. I would say Train to Busan has defeated all of them...engaging , thrilling , emotional and so much more.. Probably I now know why South Korea comes up with so good films..
Hats off to direction, content and actors.
Khamsameeda to entire cast...
Sarange to the small little girl......

Oh what a beautiful movie it is! At first I thought it may be a as usual movie like other Zombie movies,but the director prooved anything can be made from anything! Very heart touching ❤,full of suspens, emotion and thrills.... and the end scenes.... just amazing!

This was good. Really good. Very fast paged zombie movie and good one for a long time.Story goes how a father and his dauther have a plan to go visit with his ex-wife with train.Story shows very good how some people get passive, some get selfish or freeze and wait death.

Survival element of this movie for me is better especially when its action only happen around the train station, railway and in the train itself (suit with the title) with the zombas(zombies) that for me their faces are not too much. For the audiences that love to 'cut an onion', the family and humanity scenes had touch my heart even my tears didn't fall down. The duration is around 2 hours and I didn't even feel it was already 2 hours after I watched it.I felt so entertained until I make a big hole of my mouth in the hall and luckily, the hall was too dark and I was sitting far from anybody – I sat in the COUPLE SEAT, alone. Maybe I easily felt entertained with this movie because of the less information I got before watching the movie. I knew the movie had viral long ago and I even knew it was about zombies two or three days before I went to the cinema. I also never watched the trailer. So it gave me a different experience of entertainment while watching it with less information of (it would be the same to another movies). This movie was succeeds to attract me into its universe till the end, and I didn't really find the detail elements of what made this movie was so entertaining to me. It was enough for taking me to the end of the story.
My main warning is a little different than most reviews. Story is powerfully told. But because of this, the movie has a Lot of sad moments. Be prepared.....

Review title: Highly Entertaining - Climax after climax, not a single minute is wasted.
Review_body: If I have not watched the trailer, I will give it a score of 10 for its entertainment value but having seen the trailer, a little is lost. I don't remember having watched any movie that is so damn engaging, so easy to follow, and so exciting right from the first few minutes all the way to the end. All the exciting moments end with a climax that's fit for a movie. The few minutes during each break for audience to catch their breath is not boring or wasted, perfectly used for characters development. I don't understand why someone commented the last 30 minutes is not as good. I find each climax better in the next. If they make a sequel to show some happenings elsewhere with the same plot and concept, I will still watch it.

Review title: A masterclass in how zombie films should be made
Review_body: This film is one of the best zombie films I've ever seen I'm normally not a fan of zombie movies but this film really proves that there is still originality left in the zombie horror genre overall I was blown away by how brilliantly made & brilliantly acted this film was

Review title: Overcoming the language barrier has introduced me to a whole new world of great films
Review_body: It started with Parasite. Now this movie. I am in love with South Korean movies. This is probably the best zombie movie I have watched.

What can I say? 28 Days Later is my top zombie flick of all time and this is the only other Zombie flick to rival it. I am utterly impressed and the humanistic touch and emotional connection I had with these characters was an amazing feat created by the writer and director. This is the third Korean film that I've watched after watching "The Chaser", which turned me on to Korean Cinema and "The Flu" which was excellent. This is a fast paced, high octane, thriller with an unforgettable ending. After watching so many trash films that have open endings, I can appreciate that Korean Films don't engage this style. I'm becoming more impressed with their films than ours. This is coming from an American viewer. Korean Cinema has a new fan! 👍🏾

I had read a lot of rave reviews about the movie and believe it did good, even so better than I expected.
Looking at the budget I think this was perfectly made.
The movie had some minor errors which could be easily overlooked since the rest of it was so brilliant. The climax just just so outstanding- it was so emotional and intensifying.
I'm a sucker for zombie movies, and that one had saspens, it was emotional, it gad zombies! So a big big yes from me
A very well designed zombie movie. Showing love a man towards other people and love of a man for her wife and daughter.

Is this really a zombie film? I am not a genre expert so I am wondering whether this is truly a zombie film: the hordes have never been buried. Also, it seems that infection comes as a result of an airborne virus and not through contact.
The acting is fine. I also like the theme of greedy capitalist industrialist not caring for society.Finally, to the comments: the schoolgirl  but I think she is not a cheerleader. She is dressed in her school uniform because this is field trip.

Wprty watching thriller with an good performance and great direction
And the climax is gonna blow ur mind
With an emotional touch.

This is a great zombie film for several reasons. Firstly pretty much all of it is filmed in broad daylight so you can see what is going on. Secondly it's pacey without going completely over the top in the action scenes. Thirdly there is characterisation and not just gore. You care about these people and want them to live. Fourthly it is quite well acted (the little girl is fantastically good and will break your heart) and very well directed. Yes it is a bit silly and overlong and is more of an action adventure film than a horror. The infected have not died so are not really zombies and there is none of that "let's see how many ways we can destroy their brains" which seems to be the only raison d'etre of most zombie movies. The effects are great without dominating the picture with the hordes of infected pouring out of glass windows and doors extremely well done.I will definitely seek out more Korean movies.

THE MOST THRILLING MOVIE I'VE EVER WATCHED. The chaos was so constant throughout most of this movie. I was on the edge of my seat the whole time. This only made the humane moments stand out more. Ma Dong Seok and Gong Yoo's character arcs had the perfect set up and emotionally PAYED OFF. Every performance was on point! You could just see the fear portrayed in detail on everyones faces. Even the extras! Every dialogue flowed naturally and realistically. The zombies physical movements and make up were so believable and executed well! All of this only added to the fear and panic instilled on viewers and portrayed to perfection by all the characters on screen. It was brilliant writing-wise, the way every character had such diverse characters with different perspectives, arcs, motivations, and belief systems all intertwined and played out like a domino effect. Massive tear jerkers, in a good way. I was sobbing so much near the end. Solid Film!This movie showcases human nature so accurately.

Review title: Not the average zombie movie, this is something else!
Review_body: First of all, this movie nailed suspense. I was kept interested throughout the film. This movie didn't only focus on the zombie apocalypse, it instead focused on the decisions made by the characters and controversies between the desperate people.It's a really unique take on zombie movies.Yet it's effective on keeping the audience on the edge of their seats.Definitely recommend!
This movie was fire. It's the best Korean zombie movie I've watched so far. The emotions were pretty high. The characters were all A1.

Although I feared the whole "absent dad" story and it being Korean, it proved to be a really solid zombie movie.I can't put my finger on it exactly what makes it "good", it just is. There's a certain atmosphere of fear and doom that is kept up throughout the film, kind of like in Perfect Sense, combined with a bit of Source Code vibes (cause of the whole train thing and sense of urgency).I'm quite sure, that if you watch it, you won't forget it. The pacing and cinematography is good, and you'll probably get some "feels" out of it too.

Review title: An individualist Broker running away from zombies
Review_body: A typical American movie from the Korean's point of view, that's enough to pay my ticket. Beyond the zombie cinematic, and great and atypical action scenes, Train to Busan contains some critics to the western culture. In one of them It makes a critic to the individuality through the role of a Broker, a Korean in an typical American job, who fights for his only life and that of his daughter, forgetting the life of anybody else. Every man for himself or a sense of community. American perspective or Asian fellowship culture.

WOW! This movie delivers! One of the best horror let alone Zombie films ever! Great acting, great story, great effects, What a ride! No messing around 15 minutes in and all hell breaks loose, and doesn't stop! Glad I stumbled on to this one, what a gem! In a time where there is a different Zombie movie or show coming out all the time, this one definitely stands out, just watch it!

Review title: A lot of brains for a zombie flick
Review_body: An emotional and terrifying dissection of what it is to be human. Social satire competes with melodrama and gore into this frenetic South Korean horror triumph. Movies about the undead have essentially been built on a foundation of fear of our fellow man. Yet TTB takes that a step further by building on the idea that, even in our darkest days, we need to look out for each other, and it is those who climb over the weak to save themselves who will suffer. Performances are outstanding all around, especially from the young Kim Su-an who incredibly makes every nightmarish scene seem utterly real.

Review title: Train to Busan resembles with Snowpiercer in which both film main setting was on the train but twisted with Zombie Apocalyptic Plot.
Review_body: Before Train to Busan became popular when it reaches big screen across the globe, I thought It will have a resemblance with Snowpiercer a film which was also directed by a Korean director, Bong Jon Hoo. What's differ with this Train to Busan film is, it is purely Korean made from director to language and it became popular over the social media because of the uniqueness of the Title.Train to Busan resembles with Snowpiercer in which both film main setting was on the train but twisted with Zombie Apocalyptic Plot. However, just like previous zombie horror sci-fi film, there's nothing special with the zombies in Train to Busan from how it was spread and how zombies reacts with uninfected ones. I loved how the train gives major role in the film however, despite they are inside the train, the story is something that so usual among zombie horror film. One bad point is, they are always in a group; a group with different personality and objectives which for me is platitude to give a thrilling rising in action. Story is not that unique, cliché, plot holes and impossible scenes are present in the whole duration of the film. It's the same as usual zombie apocalypse with no major changes of plot. Train to Busan is definitely a simple Zombie Horror Film that do not gives adrenaline satisfaction of it's common and bad story line. But still a must watch movie for Zombie Lovers.
This the best movie among all zombie movoes i have watched. Teaches us what you give comes back to you !!

I am not big on the zombie genre, thinking 'enough with the whole zombie thing already' camp. BUT...this movie is just too much fun to watch that it makes one more zombie movie incredibly tolerable. Did I read that there was a movie before this one called "Seoul Station"? Ah, I just read that Seoul Station is an animated film, and I am not big on those either. But, I'll have to find it and watch it now. And now I want to rewatch 'Snowpiercer' and '28 Days Later'. Actually, I want to see 'Train to Busan' again already.
What a great film, the character building, the zombie scenes were amazing. Very well done!

The plans, the direction, the rhythm, the character development, swim do nothing without any reason, suspense well taken and perfect rhythm, the bad thing is the poor vfx and not showing the origin of the plague I think

Review title: The best zombie movie I've ever seen!
Review_body: All I can say is if you like zombie movies, this is a must see! The storyline, characters,setting all great!
Can't remember the last time I enjoyed a zombie movie this much.... Was practically on edge.... Was fun.

Review title: Get on Board because you're in for a Ride!
Review_body: This is a must see for zombie enthusiasts - what a ride! I was on the edge of my seat the entire time. First off, the characters are colorful, yet easy to relate to. I would say the supporting characters are some of the best and well written characters I've seen in a horror genre...ever. I was pleased to see there was a lot of attention to detail on each and every character. The location is unique (98% of the film is shot on a moving train) and it really adds to the high stakes, fast paced, high stress environment. I thought they did a great job creating a space and environment that really added to the story in many layers. It was thematic, metaphorical, helped pace out the film, and overall it was a great visual. This is a must watch.

Review title: Now this is a zombie film!
Review_body: Really fresh take on the tired zombie genre - it's an emotional thrill-ride that doesn't let up.

Review title: The little girl in this movie....
Review_body: Is amazing. I usually don't like child actors too much, but she's incredible.
Go for it without any doubt. Awesome story and superb execution.

Review title: Must watch for any zombie fan!!!
Review_body:
First off, you should know that I don't like to watch foreign films because I hate reading subtitles and I only go to theaters 5-10 minutes away from where I live. When I watched the trailer for Train to Busan, I knew I had to see it in a theater. The day it came out in the U. S., I drove 20 minutes to the only theater showing Train to Busan. I was not disappointed at all. The theater was packed. Train to Busan kept me literally on the edge of my seat. I found myself on an emotional roller coaster ride while watching this perfectly executed action packed zombie movie. I was so invested because the characters were so well developed. (Make sure to have tissue handy when watching this movie because I was not the only one crying during the movie, I could hear sniffling all around me in the theater.) I recommended this movie to my cousin who also loves zombie movies. She was hesitant about driving half an hour to see it but I convinced her to go. I got a big thank you text from her after they left the theater. She said it was well worth the drive. I have since watched this several times at home and I still cry but I just love this movie!If you are into zombie movies, you MUST watch this. If I had to rank my top 3 favorite zombie movies with 1 being the highest/best, they would be as follows.#1 Train to Busan
#2 Zack Snyder's Dawn of the Dead
#3 28 Days LaterThis is the only foreign film that I've watched in a theater as of today. Note that I always find fault in almost every movie I watch. I could not find anything wrong with this movie. I was, however, very sad that a character was killed off to the point of crying like a leaky faucet. And even so, I still can't say that it should've ended differently.

Review title: Great movie up to the last 30 minutes
Review_body: With such a high presence in both TV and film, zombies are becoming over used. Our fascination with them seems to quickly be coming to a close, so it takes something special to stand out. First time live action director, Sang-ho Yeon, has managed to craft a unique take on the undead by placing them on a train and adding a few things to their mythology. Despite underdeveloped characters and an overly sentimental final act, Train to Busan delivers a fresh take on the zombie movement that contains some extremely memorable set pieces. The story revolves around a father who is taking his daughter to see his ex-wife. Yoo Gong plays the typical father who is more concerned with work than with family and does not always put people as his top priority. His daughter is the typical kid who knows how important other people are and always tries to do the right thing. This is where the film really falters. The characters fit perfectly into stereotypical roles and never feel like anything other than placeholders. There is the typical villain who never seems to die, the typical female characters who must rely on the men, and the group of people who blindly follow orders. There is one excretion however. During the train ride, the father and daughter encounter a couple with a child on the way. The man in this relationship is charismatic, charming, and above all, badass. When everything is about to go down, he is quick to suit up and prepare for a fight. This is the one character in the entire film that stands out and quickly becomes the reason you root for the characters to make it out. There is also an incredibly emotional scene involving this character that really hits hard. The build up to the scene works well and because we are so attached to him, anytime he is at risk the stakes are raised. The scene is effective and almost brought tears to my eyes. This scene should have been the emotional climax of the film. Unfortunately the film goes on for about 30 more minutes and involves another emotional moment with the main character. This second scene however is not effective at all. Through flashbacks and an awkward script, the scene becomes cheesy and at a certain point comical. It didn't work and really took away from the previous emotional climax. Typical of the zombie genre, the film does contain a social critique. Similar to Snowpiercer, the film uses its setting to comment on the class system and the social order we fall into. The businessman is ultimately the boss as he is superior in pedigree and it is up to everyone else to follow him or be cast aside. Additionally his character perfectly aligns with the dog eat dog world we live in today as he uses others for his own advantage. As he throws people to the wayside, literally to be devoured by those around them, it is clear the point that is being made. Also borrowing from another film, the zombies here are fast. Just like in World War Z, they act like swarms of insects as they barrel through doorways and windows creating a sense of urgency slower zombies often fail to establish. They also look great. There are a few moments when they all swarm together, where it is clear CGI was used, but for the most part they used practical effects. The zombies move with disjointed, quick movements that make them very terrifying. It is almost painful to watch them contort their bodies as they converge on their victims. The real unique characteristic though is that they cannot see well in the dark. This trait provides the basis for a number of intense set pieces as characters use sounds to mislead the zombies and navigate the claustrophobic setting from train car to train car. Another great set piece involves the characters getting off the train. It appears as though they have reached a safe zone, but once they realize that they are mistaken, it becomes a race to get back on the train. Characters are killed, people are injured, and bonds are formed as people realize how much they need each other to survive. It is a nice diversion from what we have seen so far and gives the audience something different, yet equally intense, so the action doesn't get repetitive. In the end however, the film does fail to keep us engaged. In the last 30 minutes, the film really starts to drag. The action is not as effective and then builds up to the disappointing emotional climax mentioned earlier. At this point, I just wanted our characters to reach safety, or die already. The very last scene however does work well. In a film filled with brutal action, it was nice to end on a heart-warming moment.Train to Busan (2016) Directed by: Sang-ho Yeon Screenplay by: Sang-ho Yeon Starring: Yoo Gong, Dong-seok Ma, and Woo-sik Choi Run Time: 1 hour 58 minutes

##No specific spoilers here, but this *is* a zombie movie.##That should be a dead give-away that: The fighting scenes will be be weak and nonsensical, mostly involving lots of people getting bitten for no good reason. (They are.) - The characters are completely retarded and suicidal. (They are.) - The whole zombie deal is going to be left without proper explanation and for every bit of plot, we'll be getting 2 giant plot-holes. (It is, and we do.)I actually started watching the movie with these as my only expectations, hoping to get some cheap entertainment. But Train to Busan fully lived up to these negative expectations, and then proceeded to add to them by taking itself way too serious. In addition to the above we get:Serious, pathetic attempts at character development. (along the lines of "I used to be a jerk but not anymore because zombies.") - Horrible social commentary. (Oh really, we should help each other, not be complete egocentric bastards? Wow thanks movie, I'd never thought of that...) - Dull dramatic scenes. (Loooong, cliché, and really only serve to get some extremely flat characters who basically have only *one* defining characteristic, who we're then supposed to be emotionally attached to.) - 4 points where the movie should have just ended. (Honestly, I'd given it a 4 or a 5 even, if it had just ended after the first 45 minutes. But it keeps dragging on and on, only ever getting more boring.) - Lack-luster fighting scenes. (Mostly just people getting bitten without doing *anything* back, because... zombies. "Oh will you look at that? A blood-covered man with ripped clothes and white eyes is sprinting towards me growling loudly and flailing his arms. Should I at least raise my arms maybe? Naw, I'll just stand here and do absolutely nothing.")I stopped watching it 3 times, and tried finishing it 2 times, but after last time I was done. I've seen like 80% and I really don't care for the ending; it's just not enjoyable in the slightest, nor is it 'deep' or in any other way worth watching. Don't waste your time if you haven't seen it, unless the idea of a zombie movie with child- level social commentary and endless drama scenes really appeals to you.

Review title: An emotionally hard hitting film that isn't just about the zombies
Review_body: Train to Busan works most effectively when building up the advent of a zombie apocalypse through unsettling images; a deer we watch get hit by a vehicle rises back up, bones cracking and wounds fresh; a line of ambulances rush past our protagonist father and his daughter on their way to the train station, the latter catching floating soot coming from a burning building in the distance; out of the window of the titular train we watch alongside the daughter a station worker get aggressively tackled for a split second without a sound.On a meta level, the viewers have been explicitly told that there's some sort of zombie invasion coming just from the deer scene alone, so it serves as a great irony as our lead characters catch fleeting glimpses of the chaos going on in the outside world from inside their cars and trains, already consumed with their own issues and destinations. The prior mentioned father and daughter want to travel to Busan in an attempt to see the mother, a couple on the train have a baby on the way. At the end of the day, they wish to see loved ones but instead are faced with zombies (who, ironically enough, wish to see the humans themselves I suppose).And it's in these human struggles where I believe the core of the film lies. Believable, charismatic performances carry the heft of zombie attacks and fights (not to discredit these scenes, they're very well directed and shot). People with everyday problems unite (or segregate) in an attempt to survive. Life-saving moves had me shouting in glee while selfish, fear-mongering moves had me frustrated. The performance by Kim Su-an, the daughter, was precious and innocent; her father played by Gong Yoo felt appropriately cold and distant until he had to rise to the occasion. Both of these characters and performances culminate in a climax that brought me to tears (I've honestly never done so for a zombie film).The zombie element captured my attention from the beginning, and the human element is what makes this movie truly work, but the genius of Train to Busan is in how it intertwines these aspects in both structure and concept.

Review title: Unrealistic Human Behavior/ All Around Stupid
Review_body: I wasn't feeling this movie and made it about 30 mins in before I had to stop, but not for the same reasons as a lot of other negative reviewers, which seem to take issue w/ the zombies' abilities themselves, that's not the issue. The behavior of the characters is so odd and unbelievable I couldn't suspend my disbelief. I'll give you some examples.1) The young daughter of the main character walks into a small train cabin to use the bathroom while train employees are dealing w/ a clearly deranged and potentially dangerous man in that very bathroom. Instead of telling her to leave they just let her stand...LITERALLY RIGHT IN FRONT OF HIM, while this man mumbles about how everyone's going to die. First red flag.2) When the zombies start attacking most people seem to just stand around like idiots waiting for their death. It was actually kinda funny to see...3) The main character gets a call from his mother and instead of immediately asking how she is and telling her to barricade the door, he just has a chat w/ her until he realizes she's already been bitten. So dumb.4) Everyone is all around way too calm w/ their current situation.Skip that one, unless you're like most people and have absolutely no standards lawl.

Wow, this movie is incredibly intense emotionally. The characters are all designed very well, so even if they seem like bad people at times or have done something wrong, you still are rooting for them because they have learned from their wrongs and are obviously being affected by them (except for one guy). It was surprising how real some of the movie felt, in terms of it not being the typical movie where everything predictably just barely goes perfectly for the main characters. This movie didn't sacrifice realism for plot convenience as much as some other movies which made it very tense and gripping. That said, there definitely were some times that they used plot convenience to set up to play with the audience's emotions, but it wasn't overdone. At times, the acting was kind of off, but I tried thinking about how they should have acted in those situations instead and couldn't think of how to execute what needed to be done. Some of the situations were just way too intense emotionally to really even know how someone would actually react in them. I enjoyed the music and camerawork as they both added to the movie quite a bit. I don't have much negative to say about this film, it was really well done and way better and more thought provoking than I anticipated.As for symbolism, themes, morals, etc., I didn't expect a zombie movie to be very deep, but Train to Busan really does force you to consider things. The main theme is finding a balance between sacrificing your own best interest for the good of others and putting yourself first. When should you ignore others in need to save yourself? Should you ever? How much of yourself should you sacrifice to help others? These questions are constantly addressed throughout the movie. The entire zombie outbreak was started because of negligence of the well being of others. There is a conflict between the father and his daughter in the beginning that is caused by him not being there in her life because he is always busy with work. His work has even caused his wife to leave him. He was obviously doing it all for his daughter's future, but when is the sacrifice too much and how should it be balanced properly? He learns early on that his daughter thinks of others a lot and does what she can for them, whereas he thinks only of himself a lot of the time which she notices and dislikes. As the story goes on, you can see a noticeable change in his actions as he becomes more and more giving until eventually he has to make the ultimate sacrifice to save his daughter. Along the way, some of his actions have almost instant karma where he will decide to risk helping someone and then they end up saving him soon after or he doesn't take the risk and it causes some sort of conflict for him. There are many characters who made great sacrifices for others and I think he saw that and always took note and saw the result of the sacrifice which helped him change and do the same. There is also a character who is entirely greedy and even sacrifices other for himself and although he does make it pretty far, he ends up infected which is very telling of where that route will get you.All in all, I believe that Train to Busan is a great film all around and is entirely worth watching, whether you want an emotional, gripping, or thought provoking experience.

Review title: A remarkable, atypical film that must be watched
Review_body: Yeon Sang-ho is a filmmaker guru and genius in that he can trick your emotions into an expectation but then completely warp your heart to feel afraid, angry, devastated, and soft all at once. He will terrify you and then make you cry hysterically. There are very few films that can move you in such a way. Train to Busan is one of those films. Oddly enough, I watched Psychokinesis after skipping over it on my streaming service for months. I'd run out of options for good science fiction so I buckled and tried it out. What a fool I was for misjudging that movie. It was so incredible that I had to see more of Sang-ho's work. I had heard incredible things of Train to Busan but, similarly to my preconceived ideas of Psychokinesis, I had my doubts of how a zombie film could be... well anything but a zombie film. Boy was I happily wrong. Much to my surprise, this film was not average in the least bit whatsoever. How dare I call myself a film lover if I've never seen Train to Busan? It moved me to a place I was not ready to go to but I am glad I went. This movie is epic, horrifying, and brilliant- An utter masterpiece.

Between The Walking Dead & every Zombie film under the sun, Train to Busan isn't overtly cliché. It does start slow, but for good reason. The suttle build up was a great idea because of the tense & life threatening moments are at every turn for most of the film. Besides the outside world, being safe or trapped on this train made made it a new situation facing a zombie outbreak that was done very well. It's fun to watch.

I have to say that we generally avoid movies with sub-titles and Asian films. We want to watch the movie, not read the sub-titles and most Asian films do not make sense to me because of the cultural differences. Train to Busan had both these as strikes against it, yet for some reason, we decided to give it a shot, fully expecting to hate it and have another selection going in short time. Boy were we wrong!! About fifteen minutes into the movie, the main characters had been introduced, the stage set and the roller-coaster started heading down the first hill. And a roller-coaster ride it was. We were on the edge of our seats: anxious, happy, sad, shocked, the full gamut of emotions.This is a zombie film, but it is an intelligent zombie film. The director does not resort to cheap gags and scenes that all of the zombie films now-a-days fall prey to. In many respects, it reminded me of World War Z and very well could have occurred in the same universe.Sang-ho Yeon, who also wrote the screenplay, did an amazing job with direction. He gave the film depth and subtle levels.Yoo Gong and Soo-an Kim, who play the father and daughter respectively, were so believable in their roles. The majority of the cast deserve praise for their work: you hate who you should hate, you like who you should like you change opinions about the ones you should change your minds about. But it does go beyond the simple classification of "good guys" and "bad guys".Whether you like zombie movies or just a good "who lives, who dies" film, give this little gem a shot. You will be surprised.

Review_body: I'd put World War Z up there somewhere and Dawn of the Dead 2004 and a few (very few) others in a top 10This had a "plausible" reason for the outbreak, and while I am not sure how it traveled so fast so quickly considering it didn't take more than 10 mins tops for those bitten etc to turn I'll let that slide. Review title: Decent zombie flick. Fresh, but not spectacular. Worth a watch.
Review_body: I thought this was a pretty decent zombie flick. The pacing was good, but this is an action film more than a horror film. This was more World War Z than Night of the Living Dead. Some of the scenes were a bit of a stretch of the imagination, but it is a zombie film, not a biopic. There were quite a bit of "feels" which is usually hard to accomplish in a zombie film, and it actually felt pretty fresh without completely rewriting the genre. The movie effectively made you like some characters, love some characters, hate some characters, you get the point.Something that bothers me about zombie movies is the inconsistency of the zombie mechanics. How fast and strong a zombie is, how fast people turn, etc. This movie is pretty notorious for this. One minute, people take what seems to be up to 15 minutes plus to turn, then next minute people are turning immediately. Zombies are jumping over objects and mangling a group of people, and then in the next scene one man can hold back an entire zombie hoard by himself without a scratch. It definitely pulls you away from the story for a moment. Overall though, this was a decent film, and I had fun watching it. In the end, this is an action/horror film that should be treated as such. Don't expect everything to make perfect sense and don't expect stellar dialog and acting, although the acting is very decent for an action/horror film.

Review title: Great story, characters, cast, and zombies!
Review_body: This movie had great story and character development that kept moving with the train. The close quarters for most of the movie kept the scenes intense and immersive. The acting was on par with a particular shout out to Su-an Kim - spectacular performance from such a young actor. Definitely worth watching!

I've seen this film mentioned elsewhere and saw it come up in my Netflix recommendations a few times so I thought I'd give it a try - especially since the user rating is impressive for Netflix and it was nominated for and won some awards.In essence, it's a fairly typical zombie horror flick but the emphasis is a complex family dynamic and mental struggle of survivors on the train from Seoul to Busan. Nobody suddenly becomes a ninja warrior or a military arms expert and not everyone lives to the end of the movie. I think that differentiates it from standard Hollywood zombie fare and makes it more compelling in the end.The acting is pretty solid and the special effects are (even though sometimes comical) surprisingly high-quality. Even though zombies are kind of played out at this point I'd recommend giving this one a lazy, rainy day viewing.

Maybe it's because of the excessive hype surrounding this supposedly groundbreaking zombie film but I was disappointed with this. This film feels like an unofficial World War Z remake in South Korea and not in a good way. There's really nothing in this film that separates it from others of its kind. It may be South Korean but it definitely feels like a typical Hollywood blockbuster.First big problem with the film are the unearned attempts at drama and tears. It's extremely melodramatic with too many attempts to touch your emotions and pull at the heartstrings, and it doesn't work because these characters are flat and disposable. They barely get any character development and are mostly just stock characters: the corrupt capitalist businessman, the dumb teenagers, the annoying kid, the hobo who speaks about the end of days, the damsel in distress, and the everyday man. They're the most one dimensional horror characters on the face of the earth who only exist to fight zombies and get eaten. I think it also says a lot that many of the positive reviews here only praise the cheerleader for being hot and not because she's a compelling character.Plus I found the "don't be selfish" aesop to be forced and poorly executed. It'd be one thing if the lead character had to learn over the course of the entire film to be more selfless and help other people as part of his path to become a better person but no, that little character arc is dropped in an instant. instead we get a hate sink character in the businessman who's presence beats us over the head with how selfishness is wrong by having him do increasingly despicable things just for the sake of it. He's not a character, just a token attempt at inserting forced and contrived conflict into the story.How to fix this? Cut down on the melodrama and remove the corrupt corporate executive and tramp characters. They're both annoying cliches (the homeless and filthy looking freak speaking about the end of days and the apocalypse has been done to death). Let the zombies be the villains for once in these movies instead of using that dumb "maybe humans are the real monsters" cliche.

Review title: The Best Zombie Film Out There
Review_body: This is certainly the best zombie film I've seen. Like most such films, this one avoids the classic but little-used-now voodoo or necromancy explanation for the reanimation of the dead, but unlike most others it does give an explanation for the phenomenon. This could have taken up half the film and weighed it down considerably, but the writers introduce it through a few deft touches which both explain what is happening and fuel the tragic plot. The cast does a good job (from what I can tell without knowing Korean), and both the action sequences and quieter moments are engaging.Horror fans will mostly like this, but it should appeal to others too, since its central characters and their predicament have universal resonance.

Review title: It wasn't flawless but still thoroughly enjoyable
Review_body: Overall, the plot and development of the story were engaging throughout. There were only a few forgivable occasions when the verisimilitude and consistency of dialogue, characters, and story were waning. To be completely fair, I really enjoyed the suspense kept throughout the entire film. The cinematography and editing captured the chaos of events really well and the deaths were neither predictable nor overdone. In the end, the protagonist reconciles his prior shortcomings and the film ends full circle. My only grief is that I wish they would have saved more characters, allowing each group to find their own way out the train station after the separation (which would have been more realistic) instead of killing everyone immediately and leaving just the daughter and girlfriend as the focal point (which is the standard but so very typical.) I also wish the writers and director would have explored the night-blindness of the monsters in an open urban setting (imagine if you had discovered that these monsters were absolutely blinded in darkness; why would you not have shared this with everyone and made your escape plans to accommodate that huge advantage?) There was huge potential with that, so I am slightly disappointed it wasn't utilized more significantly. But, in total, I think the film managed a 7/10.On a side note, I'm expecting some of these negative reviews are biased against the film for being of Korean origin. Also, the subtitles can suck.

Review title: Challenge of Korean blockbuster, and it succeeded quite well
Review_body: Making zombie blockbuster movies outside of Hollywood is not an easy task. Money is the biggest problem, of course. Since it takes a lot of money, success should be guaranteed before making a movie is decided. However, because there are no other precedents, you can't tell whether it's going to succeed or not. This bad cycle kept Korean directors from making zombie blockbusters. This tells how bold movement it was to make 'Train to Busan'. This movie was destined to be 'hit' or 'flop' and it turns out to be 'hit'. Then, this gives a food for thought. What made this Korean zombie blockbuster movie which is definitely unfamiliar to Korean people successful? Ironically, the secret lies in familiarity. Let's take a look at this movie. Yes, it has zombies, but is this movie all about them? No. Unlike 28 days later or resident evil, this movie actually doesn't care about zombies that much. Zombies are not explained much. Their origin, their ability, cure for zombiesThese are the things that are not being handled well in the movie. In this movie, zombies are just tools to represent 'threats'. The main theme of this movie is about how people react to threats. Selfishness, altruism, violence, love and much more are being depicted in this movie. And Korean people are quite accustomed to these elements. When directors mix these elements well, then the movie becomes a hit, just like this one. However, this movie still has some downsides too. Acting of Jin-hee is quite unbearably bad and the character Yong-suk (who keeps trying to sacrifice others to save himself) had gone way too far. Yes, I can get mad at bad guys but I don't want to get annoyed at them. Also, getting annoyed gets worse when it is not properly resolved as this movie does. Overall, this is a quite well-made movie, though it still has some bad moments. I believe this movie will be a new beginning for Korean blockbusters. And I recommend you to watch this movie to stay alert for rise of Korean movies.

Review title: Now this is a zombie movie
Review_body: First of all, Let's depart from the stereotypical zombie movies while using the common denominator: Outbreak. The movie is exceptional not because is good but because it has a very twisting line. You may think a favorite character will live but he/she wont. Imagine Game of Thrones, right? They die a lot. Now add zombies, add a high speed moving train, add a yakuza, some teenagers and the cliché "pregnant lady". Of course add the drama between parent and child and a WHOLE LOT of blood and gore, with no expense saved on special effects, no double the same zombie "I CHECKED". The movie is blockbuster material. Watch it, you'll love it. Regards, Syrus Gregorio.

Review title: Wow. One of the better zombie films out there.
Review_body: Busanhaeng, more commonly known in the west as Train to Busan, focuses primarily on a hard-working man who frequently puts his work before his young daughter. The man, Seok-woo, takes his daughter on an early train headed from Seoul to Busan in order for her to see her mother. What happens when they board the train, well it is quite obvious what happens. Nevertheless, Train to Busan involved a broad range of characters, although they were cliche, that offered an experience of how people reacted to their surroundings and what they were willing to do in order to survive. There is relief and heartbreak along the way, but Train to Busan is certainly the best modern zombie film, and one of the best films I have recently seen. Train to Busan 2 is supposedly in the works for a 2020 release, and I cannot wait to see how the journey continues and what is next for our cast.

Train to Busan ReviewThis was THE BEST zombie flick I've ever seen (and I've seen a lot). It's hyper intense, emotional and heartbreaking all at the same time. I've never seen anything quite like it.I absolutely LOVE how it shows the rapid decline of civilization. One minute people are just normal people. The next minute those same people are leaving children and the elderly for dead just to save their own skin. It's visceral, disturbing and ABSOLUTELY realistic (which is something zombie movies rarely are).The movie is extremely fast paced and rarely takes its foot off of the accelerator. This keeps you on the edge of your seat, and always wondering what's going to happen next.The director did an excellent job at painting a scenario where no one was safe. You feel the same way about the characters too. You really don't have any clue who's going to die next, and that's SO refreshing to me.If you're like me and love all things zombie related then you HAVE to watch this film!

The concept that the infected completely can't sense people simply because they're in slight darkness is a bit ridiculous. The baseball boy sat holding his infected girlfriend and got himself killed by her, how romantic, but stupid, and to be expected from a Korean production. The older woman opening the door to the infected because...she went crazy? I don't know. Just seemed like a way to kill off the rest of the passengers. The father putting his hand over the infected man's mouth was absurd, but heroic and cliché. Overall this movie was frustrating to watch. It was filled with logic errors, and needless actions for emotional impact and to move the plot along. I thought this movie would change my mind about the poor quality of the Asian movie industry, but I was sadly mistaken. It was still entertaining though, so a 6/10 it is.

Please don't miss out on this one! I saw this movie months ago and it still resonates.. A Train to Busan is not just a thrilling, fast-pacing zombie movie - it is as much so about friendship, love, introspection,... in short all the things that separate us from the Undead. Korean filmmakers have a clever way of mixing the genres so flawlessly (comedy, family-drama, horror), that you'll find yourself crying and smiling at the same time. The build up is perfect (The opening scene in particular is very memorable- amazing special effects). Some of the scenes are heartbreaking, the girl in particular acts astonishing well and you'll find yourself on the tip of your seat vowing for that train to make it to Busan.

As far as Z movies go our screens are saturated with them either on TV or the big screen, before i watched this i naturally thought i would see nothing new but how wrong i was.From start to finish you are taken on a roller coaster of emotions with no fancy special effects or chainsaws or guns other than some very good zombie or infected creations and a couple of baseball bats along with some very fine acting and all of this on a train.Train to Busan is quite simply the best film i have seen so far this year and i think one of the best zombie movies to date,if your a fan of this genre and your fed up with overkill computer graphic generated tripe then this is for you, take note Hollywood you main learn a thing or two.

Review title: Simply put; An irrefutably all around exceptional movie
Review_body: With a dynamic storyline and multi-dimensional characters, backed by a cast of exemplary actors, its simply myopic to try and place this movie in any one genre.Brimming with elements of Adventure, Romance, Drama, Action, Thriller and ofcourse, from an objective stand point, Horror (of an unprecendented caliber) this movie has scared me, teared me and tore me up all whilst making me overwhelmingly happy.Though admittedly falling victim to a number of banal genre clichés.. like characters freezing at the most irrational, inopportune times and predictable 'zombie-morphings'... this film has done well to redeem itself and atone for shortcomings of zombie movies before.Without revealing too much, i would especially like to commend the screenwriters for such stellar work on scripting the characters and how interactive they were made. The main protoganist took me on a roller coaster ride of emotions... I found my self being inadvertently swept from abhorring everything that he was to adoring everthing that he had become... and his daughter.. my oh my... an adorable charming angel yes.. but an exceptionally gifted actor indeed... THIS MOVIE IS A MUST SEE... no matter what you may be in the mood for.. im positive you'll find that this movie will adequately satiate ur crave.A+

This movie is two hours long, and from the moment the zombies appear about 20 minutes into the movie, it keeps you on the edge of your seat. Some of the scenes are almost unbearably tense. It is exciting but also sad because you grow to know and to like most of the characters in the movie and you don't want them to fall into the hands of the zombies.But by the end of the movie I felt not only sad but also burdened for some reason. I couldn't understand why because the movie itself was very well-made and enjoyable. And I wasn't bothered that the movie didn't end the way I wanted it to. No, it was something else.And I thought about it and I think it has something to do with the filmmakers way of looking at things, of their way of understanding the world. I know it's a fictional story of course, but what kind of a world is it where the reward for the incredible acts of bravery and of self sacrifice that some of the characters in the movie go through is to turn them into unthinking, ultra-violent bloodthirsty monsters!And then it occurred to me that it must have something to do with the filmmakers way of looking at things. It's a sad place indeed where your reward for incredible acts of bravery and of self-sacrifice is to become an ultra-violent unthinking monster. There is no redemption for these people, so they are running and fighting for nothing! Everyone here was hopelessly doomed from the very beginning.They say Jesus name in the movie but they use it merely as an exclamation as they often do in American movies. God cannot save anyone here because no one believes in him!

Review title: One of the best zombie / horro flicks out there
Review_body: *** This is a fair and even handed review - I'm not one of these idiots that marks either 1 or 10 for every film they watch because they don't understand the context ***Even if "Train to Busan" was "just another zombie film", it's one of the best out there. Ranking with the originality of Romero's Dead series, through to the panic of "28 days" and "28 weeks later", and the scale of "World War Z". It's a great "monster in the house" set up, the house being a train and the surrounding cities and stations - and the monsters, some form of fast infected sprinting zombies, that stop at nothing to prey on the living. It's worth watching just for the sheer carriage to carriage excitement, and the jerking and twisting Zombies as they awaken, along with a fresh take on their abilities.But at heart, it's a beautiful story of a fathers relationship with his daughter, and the sacrifice parents make to keep their children happy and offer them the best in life. It's filled with plenty of additional memorable characters that you form a strong bond with: love, understand, or hate - and plenty in between. It's definitely got a Korean / Manga feel. From the dread of the opening scene, the poignant score, to the special effects, and pacing - it's a great film on it's own, and even better within the genre - which has certainly been hard to do these last 20 years.It's an action packed and emotional roller coaster from start to finish, with plenty of jumping moments and even some tear jerkers!If you're a zombie fan, it's a must see, and almost everyone else will enjoy it too.8/10
