Train to Busan is one of those biological disaster films that we have all no doubt revisited during the COVID-19 pandemic with a hyper-aware familiarity regarding the effects of a virus outbreak. I, however, found myself feeling the same unfazedness watching the film a second time as I did the first time. Train to Busan was branded as a horror movie, and yet I found its jumpscares and attempts at shock to be comical at best. With a main cast that felt like the amalgamation of the most generic character tropes possible, plus cheesy scriptwriting on par with the likes of Riverdale, it managed to place a sob story father-daughter relationship above the pressing conflict of a global apocalypse crisis. For example, in some scenes it is almost as if the imminent zombie wave in the background simply pauses while Gong Yoo's character and his daughter have a spontaneous heart-to-heart, or in other scenes the zombies blatantly go limp and allow themselves to be beaten to a pulp by Ma Dong Seok where they were previously rabid and ferocious.Beyond the awkward scene transitions and unrealistic fight scenes, the overall premise of a destructive virus outbreak turning humans into mutants was frankly delivered in the least creative way. Keeping the cast stuck in an enclosed space (a train) was probably one of the lowest hanging fruits in terms of a thriller-type setting. Having been an avid viewer of Korean film and TV, I like to think I can tell apart an original movie/series created for art's sake versus a movie made primarily for cheap entertainment or to garner tickets in the box office. This film, unfortunately, falls in the latter category. Painfully forced tearjerker scenes and the constant demise of everyone but the main character contribute to an overall tone of formulaic storytelling devoid of creative risks or surprises. Train to Busan is great fun if you're looking for surface-level entertainment on a Friday movie night. But it lacks any sort of original substance comparable to the previous film that lead actors Gong Yoo and Jung Yu Mi collaborated on, The Crucible (2011), which I would say is a much more worthwhile watch.

For once it's not a zombie movie where human vs human takes the spotlight from human vs zombie. I'm genuinely satisfied with the execution of the movie overall. the acting was superb along with the pacing. My only gripe is the slew of sudden character deaths at the end, most felt a little unneeded but they achieved the goal of making me sad. but that aside I genuinely had fun watching this, my heart was beating fast with certain scenes, and I was invested in the characters. I can even look past some of the obvious CGI since it isn't bad, just obvious. Honestly, it depresses me that it's this hard to come by a good piece of zombie media. They always take the main focus from the zombies to make it something like the nature of man or the origin of the outbreak. You see a lot of zombie media having evolved forms of zombies because the writers don't think flesh-eating zombies can keep your attention. save for games that usually execute evolved infected well. Essentially I come to a zombie movie/comic/manga/anime for the zombies, and I want my zombies, Train to Busan is one of the few if not the only one to do it right. Watch this movie, you won't regret it.

This is my first review on here, and I was so blown away by this film that I just had to come on here right after viewing it to share my experience! First off, all I can say is WOW! My heart is still racing and I still have tears in my eyes (and I honestly RARELY cry in response to any film)! The characters are so well-developed and right from the beginning (and literally to the very LAST moment of the film) I genuinely felt for these characters and felt like I was actually with them, experiencing a huge range of emotions from fear to sadness to even some funny moments, all which are very sincere and portrayed by top- notch acting. I'm so tired of all the bad, cheesy, cheap movies on Netflix, but after reading so many great reviews of this film I decided to give it a try - and boy am I impressed! This is not your typical zombie film - Hollywood, please take note of this - THIS IS HOW A ZOMBIE MOVIE should be! It explores so much more than just "zombies" - it shows what is at the core of humanity and society; it explores ethics and what people will do in a crisis and to fight til the end to survive - all without going too deep or being too corny. The cinematography is incredible and the acting is really what blew me away - especially the little girl - I admit she won my heart and I was crying along with her at the end when her father sacrifices himself for her and the pregnant woman. If a film can truly make its audience care so much for its characters like this film does (kudos to the director!), it ups the tension even more and we feel a true connection to these characters - WOW! That is a RARE but fabulous thing! Please watch this movie - even people who don't like "zombie" movies will love it - perfect mix of horror, drama, and suspense! I love how the director used a very claustrophobic atmosphere and whittled it down to being even more claustrophobic - amazing! You will not be disappointed! I was glued to the screen the entire time while watching this! The best zombie movie ever - and don't let the subtitles turn you off - it is not overly dialogue heavy and the subtitles do not distract from the film! What a thrill ride! I'm still on the edge of my seat! So impressive, especially it being a foreign film - that might turn some people off but give it a try - you will not be disappointed! HIGHLY RECOMMENDED! I'm a huge horror junkie and it is a rare thing to have a horror film affect me so much - but this is more than just a "horror" film - it connects its audience with its characters in such a way that you actually feel like you are on this train to Busan right along with them! I can honestly say that I felt cramped, claustrophobic, and on the edge of my seat the entire time watching this (and I admit I LOVED it! What a ride)! I'm just so overly happy that I finally found an amazing film on Netflix! "Train to Busan" is by far the best film I've seen this past year! Simply blown away. :-D

Review title: As good as the genre gets (and that's a compliment)
Review_body: I just finished a second viewing of this film (the first was at an art house cinema) and during this second viewing, the qualities of this picture became very clear (more so than during the first one). Yes, it does contain the zombie tropes and the characters nicely fall into the stereotypes: the jock, his girlfriend, the bad-ass, the evil businessman, Jordan Gekko, the little girl, the survivor, the old ladies,...But this is where the movie's strongest asset works: like TWD, it manages to make you care about the characters. The story leaves you just enough time to connect with them. Sometimes with a slice of comic relief, although to the movie's credit, that is not overdone either. It never becomes a jokey joke-thing and that's a quality as well.Once the zombies come into play, all the right buttons are pushed at the right moment. Timing is a quality not to underestimate.The moments that are meant to be tension filled succeed in doing so (the actors do a great job at making the characters look determined in their quest to survive) and when it wants to tug at your heart strings... well, it simply does. Some moments (like with Jin Hee and her boyfriend) are touching, but there is a moment near the end between Jordan Gekko and the little girl that is simply gut-wrenching. In terms of emotional impact, it's right up there with Sophia walking out of the barn, if you will. But in a different way.So, in short, it's a success all across the board. Highly recommended for horror fans.

Being a fan of the horror genre and seeing how overused and cliched the zombie movies was getting, it was really awesome to see a fresh and entertaining idea for a zombie apocalypse. For something that could have gone down the roads of snakes on a plane this movie was wayy better than many of the zombie movies out there. You have very great actors who you can get behind and root for. You have the loving husband, a father, pregnant woman, cheerleader, college brats and you have the greedy selfish capitalist a-hole of a CEO. The overarching theme of selfishness and selflessness, survival and panic is all a key part of this movie.This movie was incredibly entertaining, really heartfelt with every character having a wonderful arc with some truly emotional scenes which is something you normally don't get in a zombie movie. I really recommend you watch this especially if you love the horror genre. 10/10 movie for me

Review title: Everything you're expecting and much more.
Review_body: Train to Busan goes from a family drama, to a zombie horror, to an action movie, and closes with the most powerful cinematic climax you've ever seen in a movie of this genre. The climax is so powerful and so sudden I couldn't even prepare to try not to tear up, it just happened. The transitions between genres blending this masterpiece together are seamless and are the backbone of its over all success.While there are a few character moments you could call questionable, if you really think about it, some people are just dumb enough to be even more irrational and stupid when fear takes over. So something that you see and go 'i would never do that!' well, maybe you wouldn't, or maybe you don't realize you might in that situation, or the person next to you might.It becomes a character study part way through, at which point you realize, the villain of the movie isn't the zombies.Over all, if you can handle the heart crushing devastation, don't miss this movie.

This flick could be during the WWZ universe, but in another place, South Korea. The zombies behave just like the WWZ zombies. Bite you, 1-2 mins later, depending on the severity of your injuries, and you are a fast running, hyper-athletic flesh eater, pulsating in crowds fighting over each other to get at the living flesh in a undead wave.Other than the characteristics of the zombies, the movie is quite different from the aforementioned title. The scope is contained to a relatively small band of survivors, trapped on a high-speed train from NW Seoul to SW Busan during the onset of an outbreak.The scope of the movie concentrates on a 30-something fund manager and his neglected 10-yo daughter, on their way to visit her mother and his ex-wife. Begrudgingly, he accepts this journey in an effort to please his daughter on her birthday, a day in which he gives her the same present he gave her last year. Much tears and reflection sets up the strain between the two and his later efforts to redeem himself.From here, all hell breaks loose. An infected passenger soon turns the bulk of the passengers on the train into zombies, in a scene very reminiscent of the WWZ airplane scene. The end result is the survivors desperately trying to survive in the enclosures between the train-cars.Like any good disaster movie, just when you think it can't get worse, it does. That is as far as I will go with the plot, to avoid spoilers.So, I loved the movie, but it requires you to not think about the logic too much, if you know anything about Korea. The fact that the infection spreads faster than a speeding train. That no guns or military presence is available, despite the fact that every Korean male is required to serve in the military for X number of years. For most western audiences, they won't notice and it doesn't detract from the fun.A++

Review title: Train to Busan: Action, Horror, and Sadness.
Review_body: Train to Busan is a movie that you probably haven't heard about. I didn't either until my dad forced me to watch it with him. He didn't tell me much about it, except that it was a zombie movie. We've seen zombie movies, the cliche walking corpses and the race to survive. I figured it would be just like them, and wasn't prepared for much. Boy, was I wrong. If you can get past the subtitles, you should brace yourself for an emotional, action-packed and morally challenging adventure, as there is nothing like this movie and I doubt there will be for a long time. Unlike well-known zombie-horror films/shows like The Walking Dead or World War Z, Train to Busan manages to create an emotional attachment to the characters. Even though the main character starts out as a prick, we still feel for him and want to see him improve. It kind of reminds of me of the movie Shaun of the Dead, in the sense of a unique approach to the cliche. Shaun of the Dead takes a more comedic and wacky approach to the cliche, with some hints of seriousness, and Train to Busan takes a serious and somewhat realistic approach, with some comedic moments, which is a good balance. The movie somehow packs in these emotional attacks with exciting unique action into a two-hour film, making it hands down the best zombie survival movie along with providing a unique and enjoyable experience.The film starts with the main character Gong Yoo (It's Korean) sitting in an office space and is depicted as a supervisor or administrator of a large corporation. He returns home for his daughter's birthday, late, and gives her a Wii U, which she already got from her mom. He also missed her singing performance, causing her to lose confidence and stutter out of singing. Right off the bat, we know that he's not the best father, but he still cares for her. Things get serious when they board a train to the city Busan to see her mother, as a strange and hysterical woman sneaks on board. Of course, that woman is what you would call a zombie, and thus the classic virus spreading action begins. While their whole city is worrying about their own zombie attack, we get to see it from the point of view of train passengers who are cramped in a small linear passage trying to survive.If you were to just look up the movie and take a glance at it, it would look silly. It's hard to make a zombie movie not look ridiculous. Now before you say "Well it's a zombie movie, isn't that silly?" While that is true, the movie somehow takes a silly and cliche concept and magically turns it into something serious, exciting, and original. Of course, there are some inescapable unrealistic moments; such as train security not noticing a clearly strange woman without a ticket board the train, or nobody regarding the woman while on the train. Those are just nit-picky things you can't avoid.Every movie has its faults, yet the faults in Train to Busan don't even come near to how amazing the film is. As I've said before, the pure emotional value packed in with exciting action makes it so great. I don't know exactly how they did it, but I can tell you that the two "Us vs Them" and "Me vs Us" themes play a big role. Us vs them is pretty obvious; a group of strangers banded together to fight the evil zombies outside, sharing resources and information. However, the Me vs Us theme goes a bit deeper. Would you sacrifice everything for a bunch of strangers you just met on a train? Or would you abandon them in hopes to survive on your own? We witness the characters go through these decisions and change as the story progresses. Gong Yoo was a businessman who wouldn't raise a thumb to help the poor, yet later on, he risks his life for a homeless man by turning back to help him up to run from a horde of zombies. After watching the movie I felt the effects of its message.Along with moral challenges, by the end of the movie, you will shed a tear. Trust me. You will feel sorrow for the characters. This is one of the few movies where I actually felt sad after watching it, and that's saying something for being a zombie movie. I definitely wasn't prepared for it, and it hit me like, well, a train. A lot of movies you will forget about after a couple of weeks, and some you will hold on to for a very long time. This is one of those that you will hold on to.

The Train to Busan is a thrilling horror unlike any I have seen before. Director Sang-ho Yeon puts his own spin on a large scale zombie outbreak, after a chemical lab releases a deadly virus. Unsuspecting passengers board a train that will cause them to see much more than the little girls mother. Innocent passengers must endure the seemingly never-ending train ride to Busan as they watch the cities of Korea fall around them, after a plant known for making mistakes releases the airborne virus. Although it as an apocalyptic style zombie fight-for-survival type movie, I wouldn't put it in the same category as some of the other prominent titles in the genre such as I Am Legend, or even World War Z.Sang-ho Yeon added a new twist and stayed away from the typical 'tough guy gunning down zombies to save the world' approach of many similar movies, and focused on capturing the chaos happening during an apocalypse in the dense modern urban setting of South Korea. The characters consistently keep the audience on the edge of their seat because of the deeper emotional connection we are able to establish at the beginning by being able to relate to them. Because the language utilized in this movie is Korean it allowed me to focus more on character's emotions and facial expressions; this, however, does not take away from the film in my opinion. One of the key strengths of this film is the breathtaking camera work and shot choice, that helps engage the audience on a new level as we are immersed into their world. A large range of film techniques are used in this film and the utilization of subjective point of view shots greatly add to the already immersive film. South Korea being the setting of the film gives the audience an inquisitive urge to keep watching as each turn and bend is foreign to us. The director's definitive choice of setting for each shot aids the suspense and "on your toes" feeling for the duration of the movie. Unlike many of the other apocalyptic movies many of us have seen, the acting in this film is absolutely phenomenal. Going into this movie I had very low expectations for quality of acting, especially since I did not recognize any of the cast from previous movies. Each actor elegantly played their roles and spared no emotion. This blew me away as most other movies I've seen like this have focused on making a few characters look badass as they power their way through crowds of zombies, but this movie was different. Each character felt real and as the audience we really connect with them, feeling like we would have made the same choices.A combination of intricate detailed set pieces, carefully chosen shots, and remarkable acting took this seemingly average zombie apocalyptic movie, to an invigorating emotionally engaging thriller that contracted my attention throughout. Not once did I feel like checking my phone or going to the bathroom, as this movie had me completely immersed from the opening scene to the the final credits.

Review title: i loved it - review for school pls ignore ty
Review_body:
The end of the world. It sounds scary, right? When we think of the end of the world some people think of an asteroid hitting the earth. Others think we might be the reason for the end of the world. Another one would be zombies somehow become a real thing and we all eventually die, fun right? Train to Busan is a zombie thriller movie that follows Seok Woo, his daughter and other passengers trapped on a bullet train in Seoul, trying to survive while an outbreak of zombies is beginning. The movie has comedic moments to terrifying moments that have you at the edge of your seat with your heart racing, wondering what happens next. I did laugh many, many times. But I also cried quite a lot, for a good amount of time but I digress. While just meeting these characters, you just can't help but care and get a soft spot for certain ones. But there are a few where you just can't bring yourself to like, no matter what. I know I certainly couldn't like a few of them. But whether you like them or not, they still have you chewing on your fingernails, wondering what comes next.
As the title says, they are on a train heading towards Busan, South Korea. As most of you know, South Korea is known for its clean big cities, mostly polite citizens, and just all around a nice place. Well those once clean and advanced cities turn into these bloody, terrifying, and dangerous places. Even before all the chaos happened, the beautiful scenery was shown just before it became bloody. You can be enjoying a nice little moment while suddenly boom! The complete opposite is shown right in front of you. I will admit I got jumpscared quite a few times. And you can bet that it will be full of bloody, neck-biting monsters.
The very first thing that you see is a man driving and he suddenly runs into a deer. Unfortunately, the deer does die and he drives off after. But what he didn't see was the deer standing back up, after it had died. Now I won't describe every single scene so a little later we meet Seok-Woo who lives with his mother and daughter, Su-an. But he really doesn't spend that much time with them since he does spend most of his time working. On his way home he lets it be known that Su-an's birthday is the next day so he buys her a Wii, but what he forgets is that he had given her one for Children's Day, yeah yikes! At this point I know I didn't like him very much, you're just wondering how could he forget what he gave his daughter for Children's Day. But, Su-an is obviously used to her father not being the most attentive father out there, wants to go see her mother in Busan. She calls her mom to tell her and begs her dad to take her or to even just let her go on her own, which would be crazy! Given that Seok-Woo had messed up once again, he agreed to take her. At this point you do feel bad for Su-an, I know I did. While there is no doubt that she loves her dad and grandmother, she just wants to go see her mom. Who knows how often she sees her, and when it's your birthday you want to see both your parents, if it's possible. So they set out to Busan the next morning.
On their way to the station you get a glimpse of the city and the emergency vehicles headed to Seoul. Ignoring what's happening in Seoul, they arrive at the station. Here is where you meet the rest of the characters. Two elderly sisters, a pregnant married couple, an awful businessman, and a baseball team. Everything is fine and everyone gets on the train but since this is a zombie movie, at the very last moment a visibly ill woman gets on the train. I honestly don't know how she got in without anyone else seeing her. I would have left that train so fast! In the matter of a few minutes, the train gets full of these violent killing machines. As we can all expect, everyone freaks out and they run, but once they figure out what's happening we have a few of them fighting back for the safety of themselves and the other passengers. Personally, in this situation I can't say for certain what I would do but I like to think that I would help the people around and at the end that would hopefully lead them to help me back. You have to work together to survive this. But Seok-Woo does tell Su-an, "At a time like this, only watch out for yourself." At the time he definitely believed this but as time went on he knew that this isn't something he should be living by or teaching his daughter. There certainly was a time where I thought the same thing, every man for himself. But it has become clear to me, that is not the case, just like Seok-Woo. Now, obviously I won't spoil anything but the survivors only survived because of the sacrifices of others.. And the selfish ones met their demise because they didn't think of anyone else besides themselves.
Before I watched it I heard many people say that it was an amazing movie they would recommend it to me but I just never got to it. Now that I watched it, I really do regret not watching it sooner. I honestly expected it to be like any other cliche zombie movie or tv show out there. It really did not disappoint at all. I liked everything about it, the characters, the plot, the way it was filmed. With the way that it ended, I certainly did not expect it at all. But I actually really did like it. Now I would express myself more about how I feel about it but I would be spoiling it so that is all I will say about the ending. Another thing that I also found interesting was the way that the zombies moved. When you think of zombies you think of them as these slow but deadly monsters. You don't usually think of them as these super fast zombies, but then again these are fresh, newly turned zombies so you definitely have to keep that in mind while watching, I know I would forget that every once in a while. Also the way they moved was pretty different. They were like spasms. They would jerk around super fast. Once again, I would 100% recommend this movie to everyone. It may not be in English but that's not a good enough excuse to not watch it. We have to expand our experiences, and not limit them to just what we know. This Korean movie is incredible! It also left me wondering how well I would do in a situation like this one. How would you do? Would you survive or would the dead consume you.

I believe this is the first review I've written.This film looked mundane and not engaging in the trailer I'd seen, but I watched it due to its high score on IMDb. It ended up being the hands-down best zombie movie I've enjoyed, with constant tension, freshness and a satisfying ending.Sometimes Korean movies of the last few years have an almost innocence or freshness which has all but disappeared from the US/UK productions, where you become truly engrossed in the story-telling and the simplicity of the screenplay works in favor of the movie. This flick is manipulative in all the right ways. It bring to mind The Thing (1982) in telling a straight-forward story that always keeps you on the edge of your seat and has you genuinely care for its characters. Highly recommended.

Review title: A movie that should not be missed!!
Review_body:
The story of Train to Busan is it about Sok-woo, a father with not much time for his daughter, Soo-ahn, are boarding the KTX, a fast train that shall bring them from Seoul to Busan. But during their journey, the apocalypse begins, and most of the earth's population become flesh craving zombies. While the KTX is shooting towards Busan, the passenger's fight for their families and lives against the zombies - and each other.
Train to Busan does a great job of using the characters as a key tool in connecting the audience to the story. And this is where the emotions and the thrill go so effectively. Because whenever a character can bring the audience to be "The same team" has been achieved. "The same team" fully. Another good part of the movie is casting a suitable cast, taking on the role, not too flattering to Gong Yoo. Looks nice and natural, it looks like he isn't high-maintenance. The shirt that you wear is smooth, beautiful, smooth, without wrinkles, even if it gets messy and dirty. And when someone else's clothes are wrinkled, they are in good shape, that is, a good clothes hanger. And what is indispensable to this is that it is a production as good as a Hollywood movie, stunning visuals and effects.
Even though the keenness in telling the point is still a little But this journey also reveals what humans and zombies mean as a product of capitalism.

Review title: This emotionally charged and zombie filled train is worth boarding
Review_body:
Train To Busan (2016)
Rating: 4/5When you are about to watch a film in the zombie genre, you have two things in mind:
1) A lot many are going to die.
2) Zombies will provide us much gore.
Well "Train To Busan" has all that in plenty, but what it has which many zombie films lack is: Emotional depth. Throughout the film we are able to connect to each character. A fund manager, who is estranged from his wife, and fails to live up to his daughter's expectations; A strongly built man and his pregnant wife; a baseball player and a girl who loves him; a selfish as hell man; two old women who are sisters and many more form characters who are fighting for survival from zombies, in a train which is travelling to Busan. Will they survive?Director Yeon Sang-ho makes sure that while he shows the undead masses of bodies attacking the passengers of the train, we are connected to each of them. "Train to Busan" is a story of survival, compassion, sacrifice. It shows us how human beings act together to fight something bigger, which felt timely as we are in the midst of a pandemic ourselves. Then there's ones who are selfish. Take this scene as an example: The fund manager and all are trying to enter another compartment of the train, but the passengers of that compartment are paranoid that they might be infected, and they try to stop them from entering.While there's gore, but the film doesn't overdo that. There's some humour sprinkled, like the scene where the pregnant woman's husband asks the fund manager's daughter whether he's her real dad, as he initially didn't like her father. There's humour, but there's the seriousness which runs throughout the film. From the opening scene where a dead deer comes back to life, we know that things are about to become tense and the entire film is very tense but entertaining.There was a scene in the film which I found a bit absurd: the fund manager, the pregnant woman's husband and the baseball player deciding to fight their way to reach their people felt a odd choice that a person would make in such a situation and I wanted the film to make more impact. But, this emotionally charged and zombie filled train is worth boarding.

When you are watching Train to Busan for the first time, you think about some scenarios, all about how to survive of course, but it doesn't at all; at the beginning you watch a family problem, and it introduces how the apocalypse start, when all the apocalypses' zombie, it's a real problem in the movie, it's not the only reason that why the movie can get your all attention, because when you think all are going well, something sad happens. But the end is something that you can imagine when you are in the middle of the movie, but not the way what we predict.
I really recommend this movie, I really like it, all the drama, and the way how the director introduce the story.

Review title: One of the Best Zomie Movies in a Very Long Time
Review_body: It is going to be hard to review this movie without adding spoilers, but here goes: I rarely watch Korean or any films with subtitles because I usually watch movies or television while doing something else. But I had read so many good things about Train to Busan, and it was Christmas Eve, so I put down all my other things and watched. What a thrill ride this movie is! There isn't much wrong with this movie and if I told you why I dropped a star from 10, it would be a spoiler!! This movie is The Walking Dead when it was new, before action and bad guys took over from the character development and relationships of beloved characters. I was entranced from the first scene. Everything in this movie is excellent. The characters are very well developed and you get attached to them. The directing is just about perfect. The layout from beginning to end is exactly what I look for in any movie. Intelligence, action, strong characters, nearly perfect flow from scene to scene. While I know most people will put this in the Zombie Apocalypse category, I beg to differ. This movie would fit in Action Adventure, Thriller, and Sci Fi just as well. While the film is about zombies, this is a much bigger movie. If you like Action Adventure and Thrillers and don't mind or can even keep an open mind about zombies, I highly recommend Train to Buran. Even if you object to subtitles, I can attest that shortly into the film, you won't even notice them. Which means you won't see a Korean film with subtitles, you will watch a movie that is simply very entertaining, even a little humor thrown in, and it will absorb you to the point that your surroundings fade and you find yourself living in this movie. That is my highest praise that I can give any movie I see. That it supersedes all boundaries and delivers a movie where you don't think of it as a foreign movie or a genre movie or a movie about politics or causes you are tired of having jammed down your throats, or politically correct language, when you just want to get away from the everyday news or your job or your health or family squabbles. And it got almost 10 stars because it fulfills that list with excellent acting and breathtaking excitement. One more thought: even the many movies I watch that can catch me and pull me in, often there is some mistake or ungainly slow period or a moment that fits in the story from the Producers or directors eye, but causes a momentary glitch in my captivation of said movie. I can't remember one moment that took me out of the movie and brought me back to reality. Just a suggestion, get all bathroom breaks and snacks out of the way before you sit down and start watching Train to Buran. And, yes, a little fear is earnestly felt now and again, also. Watch this movie!! It really is worth paying for. And movies like this, in my humble opinion, are few and far between these days!

Review title: One of the greatest horror movies -- I was shocked it was so amazing.
Review_body: Tonight, I was looking for a movie to watch on my InfinityTV.I have always liked horror movies and I came across "Train to Busan" (2016).That's right--a modern one for a change.This is a Korean movie, shot in Korea. I watched it in English subtitles.This is a horror movie with a zombie theme. I know that makes it sound very cheesy but the write-up on it made it sound like it might be different.It was. That is an understatement.This was a beautiful film. I cried at three points. There is a strong love story and life lessons about bravery/ethics for others.It has to be one of the greatest horror films I have ever seen.I will never forget it.That's right--a horror zombie foreign film in English subtitles. It was unbelievably good. The zombies were overshadowed by the stories and the rest of the movie.If you are able to come across it, I extremely highly recommend it.

Train to Busan is more than a zombie movie.
Also is about how important is a woman in our life. And about
selfishness and individual versus collective.
It is about the triumph of human life and the sacrifices necessary for human life to continue on earth.
It's easy to say that woman symbolized life in this film. In fact, the survivors are a pregnant woman and a little girl.
Because, life without women could not continue. This is the end that gives us hope for survival.
In ths movie, we are offered almost all the important representations that a woman can have, that of a wife, represented in the film by the pregnant woman (Seong-kyeong),
the one of the daughter represented in the movie by the little girl Soo-an, the one of the friend represented by the character Jin-hee, the two older sisters (possible grandparents)
In-gil and Jong-gil. Of these, only the first two survive because of the sacrifice that men from their lives, makes.
One of the two old sisters dies due to the selfishness of another interesting character Yon-suk, but the other sister sacrifices herself to avenge the death of her sister.
Jin-hee also dies because of Yon-suk and her boyfriend sacrifice, although he could very well have saved himself.
Yon-suk turns out to be a loner with only a mother waiting for him at home, hence his selfishness, to reach her at any cost, even treading on corpses.
The importance of women is often emphasized through the sacrifices made by those around, but especially because they are the foundation of our survival as a species. I didn't gave 10 because of some goofs, but really it's not so important.

I usually don't like writing reviews as I truly believe that everyone should decide for him/herself what he/she likes, but now, I just couldn't handle myself. Train to Busan is a MASTERPIECE what everyone should see. No matter if you don't like the genre this movie is a MUST watch. Sure we saw the zombie apocalypse rise a million times, and sure we already saw something like this (the straight comparison that comes to mind is World War Z) but Train to Busan shines where all of its brothers and sisters fall short. The story is really well put together, we've got all the aspects in characters we need: the dad, the little girl, the though guy, the f***ing bastard you want to kill at the end, and they are NOT one dimensional characters, you ACTUALLY come to care for them. The acting is spot on without a question. It is heavily action-packed and OH GOD it is so beautifully put together that you will actually screaming on top of your lung for them, you will try to give them advice and the excitement will eat you up. I mean I almost had a heart attack during the scenes as I was so into the movie. And the cinematography of this film is actually shows Hollywood that a blockbuster can have a wonderful art-like scenery too. And it shows something else: that you don't need heavy CGI for a zombie movie... KHM... World War Z.... KHM.... if your zombies are running. Absolutely amazing. I LOVE THIS MOVIE AND I WOULD A 100% RECOMMEND IT TO EVERYBODY!!!

this film offers a pleasent variety of emotional scenes and very suspensefull action scenes where the passengers try to fight the threat of the zombies and escape the chaos.
main acters and dialoges beneath the chaos are very authentic and well played.

Hello,First, I'd like to mention that this is my first time writing a review and second time watching a foreign movie.The movie's plot is about a virus that breaks out in South Korea (obviously) whilst our main character and his daughter board a train to get to Busan, hence the movie name, so the daughter can see her mother. 
In the first 25 minutes of the movie nothing of interest happens, but a few scenes that won't make you adjust your seating. Highlights are an infected girl entering the train and (presumably) the president giving a speech on national TV, trying to calm the citizens and telling them that there are no zombies, just aggressive/violent people + the introduction of a married couple.
Fast-forward, the train is now full of infected people and the train has to stop at Daejeon where they will be quarantined, but the train passengers are unaware, which made me confused why won't you tell them that they will be quarantined; I mean at leas they know they will be safe? Why would the train stop even that they did not see any military personnel. why wouldn't the conductor try to recontact the command center?
Anyhow, people re-board the train and several thrill and drama packed fights happen as the survivors are split onto 3 different cars and try to reunite.
Another interesting point for me here: when the husband of the pregnant wife was trying to hold close the door, why didn't anyone just try to cover it as they know the infected people would become passive after it? The husband ends up dead in a drama of sacrifice for the sake of his wife and other survivors. Moving on to the next scene after the rest of the survivors manage to regroup in the last car, they were despised by the other group and obeyed their request to leave, which was weird as they were the much stronger group + armed with bats + they just finished fighting like 20 infected people. You can clearly see the hate of Seok Woo when he looks at the COO of the railroad company (remember this scene).The train later stops because of a blockage caused by containers even though I don't see a cargo train nearby. The conductor disembarks and tells other survivors to meet at the far left railroad. 
The COO of the company again sacrifices another person (the conductor in this case) so he can survive.
Now, Seok Woo meets the COO on the locomotive but he is still scared and passive, and a very weak fight scene takes place which results in our hero putting his hand in the infected COO's mouth for some reason. Hero gets infected, sacrifices himself, his daughter lives along with the pregnant woman yay!To put this short, Train to Busan put me in an amazing mood as I adore South Korea, but there many situations that I find weird, especially the COO fighting the father! That guy just made you lose your friends and is an egoist bastard, then he even tries to attack your daughter while he is infected, all that and all you can do is Ugh and Ahh?! Maybe I am not familiar with the South Korean culture and that they're peaceful by nature, but still the adrenaline rush would've helped.
Train to Busan literally feels like a trip through Korea and emotions for me even though you don't see much, but you don't feel like an outcast, you still feel heavily related to the characters and location, but I believe that the director could've made the death of Jin Hii more dramatic as they looked like an interesting couple. I appraise the fact that it wasn't an all pink everyone survives ending, you rarely see that these days.
I hope the sequel focuses more on the damage done to the cities and people, and makes you deeply related with 2 or 3 characters only instead of mildly interested in all of them.

Review title: A thrilling ride through and through
Review_body: Striking cinematography coupled with an engaging story drives this films adrenaline filled narrative of fully realized characters, nail biting sequences, and heart wrenching moments. Sang-ho Yeon does an incredible job with the film, and the actors give equally masterful performances. Watching the film I did feel as though there was a slight translational discrepancy between the Korean of the movie and the English subtitles, and that the movie held a slightly different meaning in its native tongue that couldn't be realistically kept across the translation. This did not detract from my experience overall and should not deter potential audience members. A must-have to any zombie movie watch list, this film cant be missed. Be warned however, 'Train to Busan' is not for the feint of heart, prepare yourself, and find someone to hold close, you'll probably be glad you did.

Its a Korean Film, so you expect Korean weirdness meets Zombies. No such thing. Same make up, no dialogue, people crying all the time, even the deaths to further the plot don't really do that. It doesn't even make an effort to have characters that appeal to the audience. No clear Protagonist or Antagonist, no real attempt at keeping a flow, the story line seems to be written for a TV show (walking dead wink wink) and got picked up for a movie. If you love Zombie Movies and want to see one from another country, watch Go Goa Gone from India. Screenplay 1/10 Acting 2/10 Cinematography 3/10 Dialogue 1/10 Final product 1/10 TL;DR- Over hyped internet garbage, not worth an intelligent human being's time.

Review title: Best zombie movie ever!! Know that!
Review_body: If u haven't seen this film, do yourself a favor. Hurry! Go! I mean it!! Perfect zombie movie: terrifying zombies, wonderful characters, good good guys, grrrr! bad guys, funny at times, surprises, etc. So much fun. Thank you Yeon Sang-Ho**

Just saw this for the first time on Netflix. It has instantly entered into my top 10 films of all time, maybe top 5.It's tough to gather my thoughts, but my biggest takeaway is that this is a film about the importance of persevering through fear to protect what and who you love the most, even if it means that you become the victim to a an unthinking mob. It's about having the strength of character to do what is right and sacrifice yourself for your family and friends and to fight to the death against odds you know are impossibly against you.A very inspiring father-daughter story set against a backdrop of a zombie apocalypse happening in South Korea, Train to Busan is much more than just another zombie movie.Something I also liked that this movie pulls no punches and respects for the viewer's intelligence. The characters solve problems through clever means. There are no deus ex machina elements present. The gore and violence is shown with a disturbing steadiness rather than being over the top. The zombies themselves are portrayed moreso as humans with rabies than anything else. They don't run super fast, they don't have super strength, and they are not exceptionally durable. In this sense, the zombies are more believable. The female characters in the film are not endowed with Hollywood-ized GIRL POWER. Some of them do demonstrate bravery, but scenes are not written purely to push feminist agendas.The acting of everyone in the film was great. Exceptional credit must go to the little girl who plays the daughter of the lead actor. She was amazing and executed every scene she was in perfectly.Highly recommended.

First off, don't watch the trailer! If you're a fan of Korean cinema and modern zombies, just get straight to the film. The film has several genuinely good 'Oh my god' eye-budging moments for the viewer and they spoil some of those in the trailer.The film truly captures the stress, and anxiety of a WWZ zombie scenario. You agonize over the vulnerability of the survivors, especially when there's no Zeds in sight. It gets going fast, builds the characters surprisingly well considering they get little exposition, and kinda just keeps going on full steam for 2 captivating hours.It's not exactly all on a train, either. That premise put me off slightly as I thought it might get a little stale, or perhaps they were on a budget. But no, there's more to it. And even one or two original ideas, believe it or not.This film takes no prisoners. It's brutal and sad, but somehow keeps a certain charm. It has the most adorable child actor - who performs brilliantly imo - and whilst she's a weaknesses for the survivors, never feels like a burden to the story. You will be rooting for them at the teary end.

It's really a great movie, disregard the people dumbing it down.
I'm honestly appalled at all these shallow reviews. When a horror movie actually has depth, you're doing a disservice when you just babble about one girl who's barely in it. This ain't some silly slasher. Y'all are weird for focusing on a girl who gets maybe 10 minutes of screen time during a 2 hour movie, and you're just distracting from the fact that this is a zombie movie that is actually GOOD.Even though it ends up using one of my most hated tropes, this movie is pretty damn good. If you're completely sick of the genre, then maybe not so much. It's gotten difficult over the past decade to make a unique zombie movie, so there are always going to be familiar elements. But, it does focus on a child-parent scenario, which is not used in zombie movies very often (this invoked some of the same feelings as the short film Cargo), and the action is pretty constant so no one can really say it's boring. It definitely exceeded expectations.

I don't typically watch zombie movies and I'll admit to not seeing the beginning (it was playing in the background at a friend's place when I arrived) but we were all pretty much glued to the screen for the remaining 80% of this film and I even getting a little emotional at the end.

Well, this was a refreshing zombie flick, not "horror" or "terror" at all. I cannot figure out why it is reviewed as "the scariest movie of the year", it's not scary at all. Unless you are scared by Hello Kitty, or Asians. The origin of the plague is plausible and makes sense, we get just the necessary insight to know what happened. Character development is pretty good, taking into account it's a zombie movie and most of them die anyway. The first act of the movie sets a good pace, and then goes on with non stop action and, most important, plausible situations given the context of a Z apocalypse in a train. Loved/hated the "Bad Guy", one would expect most of humans will think and act like him. The little girl's acting in the end is very moving, 10/10. The ending for the good guy is a little dumb, he could have taken, at least in theory, that Z with no effort, he did it many times before, doesn't make sense. But, had he survived, the movie's ending would have been cheesy. So, in the long run, a good thing he died. Koreans are doing a great job delivering better and better movies, I really think this one is in the top 10 or 20 Z movies, and gives fresh air to a genre that has been flushed down the toilet recently.

Review title: Thankful that I got stranded in the mall that day! ( September 9, 2016 - Friday )
Review_body: Whenever I watch movies in the theater, I almost always choose one which is either on IMAX or 3D. My reason is that, Since I am spending my hard earned money to watch a movie on the big screen, it might as well be worth it or I'd rather wait for it on DVD or watch it online. Aside from that, since there have been a lot of awesome TV shows lately, which are written with more cliffhangers, I found that whenever I watch a 2D movie in the cold and comfy theater, I get sleepy and sometimes fall asleep before the end. Blame it on my short attention I guess. The other day I was at the mall and sort of got stranded because of a sudden downpour. And I decided to pass the time by watching a movie. I tried out the Director's Club theater at the new S. Maison beside the Conrad Hotel,and I ofted to watch the Korean movie "TRAIN TO BUSAN" because of the nice trailer that I saw on my Facebook feeds. I'll be honest, that at first I thought it was a bad decision, because I didn't know that the movie was not in English, and I thought that I would definitely fall asleep because I was so comfy in the cold temperature and lazy boy seats. But the movie was so THRILLING and ENGAGING that I was thoroughly entertained until the end, even though it was Korean and only English subtitles. Zombie plots in shows have been so common lately that I have lost interest in watching shows with zombies themes, such as "The Walking Dead" which was okay the first few seasons, but I feel was later on just been too violent and worn out.This movie, "TRAIN TO BUSAN" was a surprisingly fresh and pleasant to watch. I was thrilled and engaged in it until the ending. I recommend watching it, even if I rarely don't do movie reviews or movie recommendations. For me it was definitely money well spent. So much so, that I am thankful that I got stranded in the mall that day. the all actors and actress are good! good job to the script writers and directors and staffs,.. I LIKE IT!! THE BEST FOR ME!!

The overall delivery of the film might be good, but if you delve to the fine detail of every scene, you'd see things that a little bit off and hardly believable. Zombie fall from a chopper can still walk, even run! with fully working limbs! Zombie soldier fall from station bridge broke his arm badly, duh..physics?Dad somehow noticed and took a baseball bat that no way can be seen unless he has x-ray vision...because moviesThe bad survivors wanted to lock the suspectedly infected hero- survivors, and they locked it in other, far side, or the car? Further from the zombies' reach? in a place safer than they currently are?? What a logic. They deserve to die alright.The kid say that she rehearsed the song for the dad and couldn't finish the song because the dad was not around. So the kid either never practice the song right in the first place (because the story imply that the dad was never home and saw his daughter practicing) or the kid is full of crap. I bet its both. Sorry kid.A locomotive could tow multiple cars, with hundreds of passengers on it, and could still speed. But the the movie wanted me to believe that a locomotive slowed down just because some zombies are clinging on it? duh..physics?The Dad feeds himself to zombie, which is unnecessary and ridiculous. Same goes for the boy that gets eaten just because, I don't know, he fell for the schoolgirl that is turning into a zombie? Why? Didn't the boy show a sign of discomfort to the lady in the beginning of the movie? Did they develop a feeling or had deeply romantic experiences off screen? Making the boy suddenly obliged to do 'till the death do us apart' sort of thing and could not pull himself together? Ah never mind, they're dead and lets left the plot hole right there.Dad suddenly understood how train works. This is sheer lazyness. Sparse character setup is not an excuse to conjure up absurd thing like as if manning a locomotive is a piece of cake.There are just too many death just for the purpose of drama. The writer/director maybe want the story to be more tragic or some sort, but who and how they die is just meaningless and almost stupid. Like why the tramp was kept alive that deep into the movie with no purpose and no impact to the story other than adding another pointless bait later? I mean it could be anyone, or I can just make up some crap that the zombies get tangled in cables to buy time. Oh no..let's just make someone does poop face before they die so the audience feel sorry for him/her. Not.You know what makes a better ending? The final fight would be infected fat man vs dad, both kid and pregnant woman help their side to win the match. Whichever side wins, they get shot in the head by the military.

A lot of my fellow countrymen (Philippines) have been talking about this movie. Every site I go, it's literally filled with Train to Busan story, memes etc. I was planning to watch it anyways but I was so busy with school. Finally, I had the time to go to the theater to watch it, and now I'm reviewing it.Story: 8The story of Train to Busan is basically just surviving the train ride. There wasn't really much of an explanation on how the infection started, but it's all good. The story revolves around Soo- an and her dad, and later with the other passengers. The story progression was decent. It was intense, calm, thrilling and emotional when it needed to be. Very well done.Cinematography: 10It was visually amazing. The effects on the zombie chase/battle, the blood, the look of the zombies, the camera angles- they were all really good! I saw a behind-the-scenes video on YouTube and I was amazed. I really liked the camera angles! The acting of the actors and actresses was also something to behold.Sound: 10This goes hand-in-hand with the cinematography. It was also intense, calm, thrilling and emotional when it needed. The sound effects were properly utilized and meshed together. The emotions that the characters feel can also be felt through their voices.Characterization: 9All the characters were interesting (even that evil CEO/COO guy). There are many emotions to the characters, and each of them (or each group) have their own way of survival. The character development of the main group (especially Soo-an and her dad) was splendid. I do feel that they killed too many characters ( I wanted Soo-an's dad and the pregnant woman's husband to survive- sorry I'm bad at remembering names) but I guess I just got attached to them.Overall: 10I loved this movie. I think the Good Stuff outweighed the Flaws that the movie had. It's not perfect but it was damn near close to it (in my opinion). It didn't scare me, but it kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the intense parts, and got my eyes watery in that ending. Overall a very fun and entertaining "train-ride". Definitely worth the hype.Note: This is my first review. I'm new to this stuff so maybe I just gave this one a 10 due to my enjoyment. Either way, I hope it was helpful. Do check the movie out, it is worth your money and time!

My headline says it all Train to Busan is simply the best zombie movie ive seen in a while entertaining throughout. The Actors are superb and you care for them so quickly and are fully invested as soon as it all goes down on the Train.This is a Zombie movie but it's also a movie about a Dad and his Daughter and what a father would do and what lengths he would go to keep her safe.Truly a Zombie Masterpiece.

At first sight of this film, especially the trailer, i thought it was some sort of film which looks like World War Z, apparently they have the same background, fast running zombies in the city.However, when the film reached the time the zombies appearing inside the train, you will notice how the people reacted, this is the right moment of humanity, what will people choose at the critical moment of life and death, selfishness, lack of compassion coming into screen one by one.Despite these, you will also find how a selfish father, who always thinks of himself in the first place without paying attention to the people around him, turns into a thoughtful person, caring for people unknown to him and also co-operating with them with a hope to survive. It's hard to describe all in detail and hope you can enjoy this film in depth.

A friend of mine recommended this movie. In his words, it would be "a kickass Korean zombie flick", so naturally i went into this movie expecting another generic, dumb, goofy zombie splatter film. Boy, was I in for a surprise!First of all, the acting is spot on. All the actors are doing a tremendously great job, but for me, little Soo-an Kim totally nails it in one of the best child actor performances I have ever seen. The zombie actors are also truly exceptional and they manage to spook you, without having to rely on heavy prosthetics and rotting flesh.Secondly, the cinematography is amazing. Although the whole story is taking place during daytime, the film manages to make you feel claustrophobic and constantly nervous without having to rely on cheap tricks such as jump scares or low lighting conditions. The cuts are seamless, the colours great and, though different from Hollywood standards, it is a generally really good looking movie.What really captured me though in this film was the drama. In this genre the characters are usually very generic and one dimensional. Though this flick is, at first, not so different in this aspect, as the story carries on we witness the shifting between the dynamics of the characters, we see their personalities evolve and change, we find out about their motives, their relationships and the depths they would go for their loved ones. I personally found myself very emotionally invested to the characters (which might be due to the great acting performances),I was actively routing for them and was really moved by the movie's finale.Don't get me wrong though. This is not some melodramatic drama flick. It is still an awesome zombie apocalypse movie. It is fast paced, it is action-packed, it is gory, it is tense and terrifying and it will keep you at the edge of your seat. It is also original, it doesn't play around and will surely satisfy even the hardcore fans of the genre. However, it is also a film you will remember for its awesome story and characters and for being an overall great movie. 10/10

Review title: Spoiler alert this movie is awful
Review_body: Yes we have all seen zombie movies blah blah blah... but what grabs me in a movie is the fine line between smart characters, dumb characters, the ones that should die, and the ones you never guessed would die so soon. Basically all the characters are dumb.What do you do when you find out zombies cant see in the dark but are attracted to sound on a train? (Raises hand) I know! Crawl through the luggage compartments...... stupid. Things like this happen constantly in this movie Zombies are rushing your way what do you do? Stand there and stare at each other then run at the last minute. Or how about the time the main character closed the door on the pregnant couple when clearly he didn't have to close the damn door right away, but that just shows that he actually is a careless butt hole. Then the fat guy holds off a horde of zombies by himself and trying to shut a door while the other two dummies are trying to break in the opposite end. No common sense, they could help the fat guy first than worry about the next thing. mind you one of them even tried to call his girlfriend who was on the opposite side of the door. This movie has tons of moments were I just wanted to kick my TV in and toss it out the window. My friends and I were constantly chanting "just die. Everyone just f****ING die." The acting sucked, the little girl was the best act in the movie. Good job little girl, everyone else sucked. The funny part of the movie is when all the zombies somehow slowed down the locomotive, then when they get kicked off, you can clearly see that they're on some kind of "boogie board" bad way to spend money. I guess they didn't have enough money to just cgi that scene. I will never watch this movie again unless i want to sit somewhere and waste 2 hours of my life....... again.

First let me say all these reviews with dribble about the women is just that..dribble. Train to Busan is a pleasure to watch. It takes the classic pandemic zombie and combines it with the isolated environment of a speeding train to great effect. The pandemic/contagion element is interwoven with ideas of environmentalism and morality. Trapping the characters in an enclosed space with the monster creates tension and conflict in a way that is somewhat reminiscent of a science fiction movie set on a spaceship or an action movie set on a submarine. These elements converge as tensions rise and the movie turns to exploring the darkest, as well as the most selfless, parts of human nature in the way that post-apocalyptic movies seem to do so well.This ideological framework is brought to life by some fantastic acting and great character writing that really draws you into the movie. The cinematography and visual storytelling are exceedingly well done and create a distinctive atmosphere. This is a movie that feels like it was built off of many well crafted details.Train to Busan isn't particularly gorey or terrifying and leans more towards the action/thriller category. It creates intrigue through the failings of the characters and humanity as a whole as well as the hope for redemption. Although the movie becomes a little "over the top" towards the end, it doesn't prevent this movie in being 10/10.

I've seen my fair share of zombie flicks and this one's up there with the greats, easily. 
The zombies in the this movie's are so brutal and portrayed in such a unique way. It never gets boring. Not for a moment. (Some damn good pacing)
The acting from the entire ensemble is on point. Totally sold me on their performance.
There was some moments where the lead characters had to make some pretty difficult choices. That kinda thing always happens in a zombie film, but they dealt with it a fresh way and me care for these characters even more.
The best thing about the movie's the hordes and hordes of zombies! And when talking about a zombie movie, it feels so refreshing to say that. (I wonder how many extras it took to get that many zombies)I also want to mention something which is so important to me in a horror movie: Subtlety.
There were scenes where zombies or the infected would just hang around in the back of the screen, sometimes not even in focus and the camera would just glance over it. That makes it so much more real and scary. It's nail biting from start to finish and completely worth your time. Go for it!

Review title: One of the best Zombies movie!!
Review_body:
Train To Busan, it's a south korean horror film, directed by Yeon Sang-ho. it lasted 118min ( it's one of the best 118min in my life Xd ). This movie is set in South Korea!
It started with Seok-Woo ( Gong Yoo ) who accepted his doughter's request, which is to take her to Busan to see her mother, because it's Su-An's birthday ( Well.. Su-An is the daughter:) ).. But the journey has been disrupted by a hellish on-board zombie outbreak.. And the real story begins... Who will survive? and How?
I think that it is more than a horror movie, because it shows how selfish, greedy a human can be... And It makes you realize how precious your father is. He is the one who will make many sacrifices for you when no-one will.. 
The ending was especially well-done and sentimental. A child who saved lives through her singing.. Which make me realize that music makes us feel secure..
Overall, ' Train To Busan ' is the best Zombie movie ( It's exciting, emotional and heartbreaking ) with a good child actor! Also the performances are convincing...
If you are a Zombie fan, you should definitly give this movie a try ;).

Review title: For those who haven't had a chance to check this gem out. WATCH IT
Review_body: First, We're going to need to do something drastic. Get out your scissors. No, not your real scissors; abstract scissors, scissors of the mind. Imagine all of your preconceived opinions about this blood-filled zombie flick. Snip Snip. Forget them. This movie is chalk full of creativity, colourful character setups and fist-pumping zombie fighting action. Not to mention a few heart pumping scenes where a wrong step could mean instant lunch for a hungry pack of flesh eaters.The ordinary people thrust into a claustrophobic zombie train scenario was fantastic and lead to some very tense moments I never thought I would see in a zombie film. And seriously, just imagine that horrifying scenario. Being stuck in the zombie-infested passenger car of a train going 100+ miles per hour. Throw that train safety video out the window because nothing could ever prepare you for this mess.Fantastic performances with a few exceptions, surprisingly good cinematography and Korean melodrama fit for a zombie apocalypse. The good outweighs the bad here and that's all I can really ask for in a Korean zombie film because it means their is a potential for more.8/10 zombie thumbs up

Review title: Great character development, may have you sobbing.
Review_body:
I'm not that into Zombie flicks, but I really liked this one. Aside from the zombie grappling action scenes which were pretty cliched, the truly compelling characters and the interactions between them is what makes this film a 10 for me.
The fractured relationship between the overworked 'arsehole' dad and his despondent daughter as he begrudgingly escorts her on the train to Busan so she could see her mother on her birthday, the two old ladies who have clearly been close friends for life, the true arsehole of the film who's only interest is his personal wellbeing, the possibly schizophrenic tramp, who people look upon as undesirable but grows in character and regard as the film progresses, and many others. But the star of this film is the little girl who is so expressive her story is written on her face and through the body language she has with her father and the people she meets on the train. 
 This film is pretty cheesy on the face of it, I mean what would you expect from a Korean zombie film. But It goes without saying such well developed characters in such a desperate situation lays bare in the most explicit way, human nature, the good and the bad. And some scenes will have even the most hardened hearts having to fight off a tear or two.

Review title: So I've never been the biggest fan of zombie films so I decided to give them another chance and look up some of the "best" of them online.
Review_body: Seok-woo (played by Gong Yoo) is a divorced fund manager who tries to have a relationship with his estranged daughter. Due to his workaholic nature he rarely sees and talks to his daughter so when she asks him to go to Busan to visit her mother for her birthday he reluctantly accepts. They board the train and depart. However right before the train sets off a strange looking woman enters it seemingly running away from something and with a bite wound on her leg. We soon see that she has been infected with something and she starts attacking the train attendant. After that chaos ensues and we see the people that have not been infected try to move to the front of the bus to evade the zombies. We are introduced to Sang-hwa and his pregnant wife Seong-kyeong, a high school baseball team, the person we will all love to hate Yon-suk, two elderly sisters In-gil and Jon-gil nd and homeless man.My favorite character was definitely Sang-hwa. I absolutely loved him as a character and he was the type of character that you would love as a person and not just a fictional character. The main character was not as interesting for me but it was really enjoyable watching him turn into a totally different character and grow throughout the movie. The acting overall was great and the actors really made for feel worried for them especially the little girl.As someone who usually dislikes zombie films this movie really surprised me in the best way possible. The story and cinematography were amazing, the pacing was done perfectly and the setting was the ideal place for this kind of movie. It really brought out the feeling of claustrophobia and hopelessness as the people were just one door away from a horde of zombies. The drama in the movie was also very good and watching the people deal with the situation as well as deal with themselves was very entertaining.If I had to point out the things I disliked about the film it would probably be the cliches. There were a few cliche characters that you would expect in a movie like this which were annoying at parts. There were also a few plot points which I disliked that seemed to be only there to make you feel a certain way about certain events and characters.Still the movie was far, far more enjoyable than I expected and I am very glad that I decided to watch it. Check it out for yourselves and let me know if you enjoyed it as much as I did.

Train to busan fits nicely in the middle and offers an enjoyable ride without breaking any new ground. Writing was poor and I felt like watching a movie instead of living an adventure, some scenes just were so unbelievable to me.An other critisim would be it's not smart enough to be a thriller and not scary enough to be horror. Something an other great Koreanen flick did achieve, the wailing. Other greats such as 28 days later and the old g.a. Romero's still stand as the best in this genre and clearly won't be topped by t2b.Ultimately t2b failed to deliver upon the hype but in the end it is well worth a watch.
